text:
Daniel Martins and Piotr Czajkowski, no that is the defeatism that plays into the strategy regarding those that don't want to do anything about the issue.

Layback Studios and TheCatLord, there was a lot of careful planning and negotiation into the Paris Accord.  It was based on the assumption that it is fair for the major causes of the problem to take on a bit of the earlier share.  The USA is by a good margin the largest historical emitter, both per capita and the country as a whole.  The agreement was fair, and in fact even generous to the USA in some respects given our country's primary role in the existing greenhouse gases.  One could argue that nobody knowingly wanted to change the atmosphere in this way, but consequences are consequences.  No amount of selfish economic interest posturing will change that especially when our country is most easily poised to make the biggest difference early on.  There are Saudi Arabia sized energy efficiency gains to be had in the USA, and that is just efficiency, not counting energy conservation, R&D, and lower GHG sources like nuclear, etc.

author: olan levan

text:
@Garrett Wright

In science you test your theory by putting twice the effort into disproving your theory as you do proving it.  You welcome skeptics, and debate them.  Theories are expendable.  In climate science they demonize skeptics.  Call them flat-earthers or deniers.  Denier is a not so subtle inference to a holocaust denier.

In real science scientists rush to be the first to make a brilliant new discovery.  In climate science thousands of scientists rush to the same brilliant conclusion at the same time over and over again.  

Their conclusion is ALWAYS the same:

 "It's worse than we thought.  Unless we drastically cut emissions within ~10 years we will face certain climate catastrophe within ~30 years."   When have I heard that before?  So many times, starting about 30 years ago in 1988.

"It's already happening, there were heat records (here), (here) and (here) and cold records (here) and (here) A 100 year flood (here).  Record snow (here)  A drought (here)  A category 4 hurricane that made landfall in the hurricane belt during hurricane season. There were wildfires (here).  Tornadoes struck Tornado Alley."

We will call it proof of climate change when it's proof that we have severe weather events.  Are they getting worse?

Severe weather is nothing new, just ask Noah.  Whether you believe bible stories or not, the Israelites knew what floods and droughts were thousands of years ago, severe weather events are nothing new.

I am not saying Earth is not warmer than it was in 1850, but there is no proof the minor warming was caused by man.  What caused the 3000 year long roman warm period?  It wasn't cars.  Climate change was so abrupt The Sahara turned from fertile to desert.

And if it was, just because the physics, research, science and observation say so it JUST CAN'T it just can't be CO2.

"What caused the 3000 year long roman warm period?" YOUR IMAGINATION. There was a "slightly" shorter northern hemisphere warming period. This was a time of fluctuating temperatures and had periods of both warming and cooling. "The Roman Warm Period, or Roman Climatic Optimum, has been proposed as a period of unusually warm weather in Europe and the North Atlantic that ran from approximately 250 BC to AD 400." Which "suggests that southern Aegean mean SUMMER temperatures in the 4th and 5th centuries BC were WITHIN a degree of modern temperatures." ie cooler by a degree. I was due, not surprisingly, to changes in solar and volcanic activity. Today, in the northern hemisphere, the end of fall occurs when we are closest to the sun, meaning milder winters. 2500 years ago, closest approach occurred in the middle of fall, meaning an elongated warm season.

The reasons then are not the reasons now. Solar has been decreasing since the late 1950's while temperatures go in the opposite direction. 





"In science you test your theory by putting twice the effort into disproving your theory as you do proving it." Yet YOU put no effort into disproving your claims, so clearly not science.
author: James Pyke

text:
Yes I agree that they could be charged mostly at night, but peak demand is right after sunset.  They should be put on timers, so they can be after 11:00PM when there is less demand.

I won't live my life scared.  I don't believe people will kill the planet with their cars.  I really don't.  I don't think people will give them up without a fight.   People won't put up with a $40.00 a gallon tax on fuel. 

There is so much about climate we don't understand.  But we will all die, well whatever... I won't worry about it.  I won't wait for a bus when I have a car.  Except for my daily commute because downtown parking is too expensive.  But using public transit to get around outside rush hour, to do errands.  No.

And Catastrophe is always ~30 years away unless we drastically cut emissions within ~10 years.  I am in New York now.  And SUVs are everywhere.  We aren't getting rid of fossil fuels anytime soon.

Look at what happens when the tax on fuel (and heat) gets too high.  Revolts, like in France.  I know it wasn't the only factor.

You want to believe people will buy expensive EVs.  Or that batteries can store enough energy for industrial economies, be my guest.  But what 300x the annual production of batteries would be required to keep up with Germany's  energy needs for one week of no wind.  They are only about 1% of Earth's population.  And batteries lose their effectiveness over time.

I am tired of people trying to chip away at our freedom, to "Save the planet." 

Yes I agree that CO2 is a greenhouse gas.  But what effect will restricting industry do.  If the oil comes out of the ground it will be sold, and burnt.

And ridiculous solutions like biomass and biofuel.  The lumber industry must think we are stupid if they believe we think burning wood is carbon neutral... Yep destroy wilderness to plant fast growing trees.  Destroy rainforests to plant palm trees.  NO that is not a solution.  Hasty decisions are often bad decisions.

 Maybe you can afford an EV, but I can't.  Are you trying to ban my little car?  Or tax me out of my car?

And how efficient is a diesel bus anyway?  So often the run with 2-3 passengers. 

We need cheap energy to thrive.  If we tax too much industry will move to lower tax jurisdictions. If all countries adopt a tax, industry will move where taxes can be avoided by paying bribes.

There is no solution every year, except during recessions, consumption goes up.  What do you think the IPCC will say in 2040?  I know, "It's worse than we thought, unless we drastically cut emissions within ~10 years we face certain climate catastrophe within ~30 years."

 Yep, record heat (here) record cold (here) record wildfires (here) 100 year flood (here) a cat 4 hurricane hit (here) (in the hurricane belt in hurricane season.)

We can reduce our footprint as a country but if we keep consuming the same goods that are now imported it won't make any difference.

Science says, is a commonly used phrase as though science is black and white. It is far from that and it changes continually. It is exploration but not, particularly in climate science can it be used as the definitive of what is happening.
In other words, just because some scientists say this is happening and we must act on this does not make it sensible to do so blindly. Unfortunately, this is just what politicians do, as broadly speaking they have little knowledge of the matter. Al Gore is a prime xample of a politician who does not understand what he is always talking about.
The IPCC is a body that governments listen to but there is a difference between the statements they make and the scientific evidence in the annexes which show far less confidence in their reports.

text:
Causes of climate change

Transportation: cars, trucks, semis, airplanes, motorcycle, ATVs
Energy: internal combustion engine generators, natural gas, coal power plants
Meat farms: cows pigs chickens and all meat but cows are the worst
Construction: concrete, smelting
Industry in general

Solutions
Energy: SOLAR panels, wind energy, BATTERIES, pumped hydro storage, nuclear, hydrogen
Transport: electric cars trucks busses trains motorcycles and ATVs, hydrogen fuel cell planes and ships
Construction: innovations in construction material beyond concrete, smelting without using coal

Makeshift solutions/slower long term repair
Direct carbon capture and carbon capture devices activated when there is to much energy to prevent waisted energy

But most of the changes aren't policy (policy helps) but it's the people that will have to change to hit these goals.

Everyone and every business has to get solar panels, batteries, electric vehicles and go vegan

text:
As for the people saying that the Earth has been much hotter, yes it has, but life had millions of years to adapt to that kind of fluctuation in the climate. The people, plants, and animals have had less than 300 years to try and adjust to the rapid rise of the global temperature. Millions of creatures and plants have died, been cut down, or burned for human gains. All of the carbon, CO2, methane, and other gasses have been released from plants when they are cut down or burned, these gasses go into the atmosphere and raise the global temperature. There is so much land that is being turned into deserts because of the rising temperatures. There is only so much that I can put into a YouTube comment about this major issue. This is just some of the things that is making our planet worse. We only have 1 planet, we aren't leaving anytime soon, so we need to get on the right path to slow global emissions and stop the rising temperatures NOW!

The global temperature will probably rise more then 2 degrees if Republicans are allowed to stay in power. We need democrats in the government because they will maybe actually do something about this global crisis.
author: Krusty Krab

text: The Earth has always been doing 2 things: warming or cooling.   We have ZERO control over it.   Where is the proof that taking some carbon out of the air is going to drop temps? Folks, do you really believe our climate is so fragile all you have to do is pump some carbon in or take some out to adjust the temperatures?   That is not science.   It's junk science.

text: This collage puts quite a bit of blame on the GOP for the hypocrisy they've displayed when it comes to climate change. I believe we are to think Dems are on the right side of this given the videos presented here, they are not.  Nancy Pelosi deserves a fair bit of blame as well.  In response to AOCs sit in for climate change attention, Pelosis response was to place Joe Manchin the guy whose campaign had had him shooting a stack of papers labeled 'carbon tax bill' with a gun, as a leader on the energy subcommittee instead of say AOC or really almost any other Democrat .  This appears to be retaliation for humiliation done by AOC in pointing out Pelosis record of taking money from the same special interests as newt Gingrich, Boehner, Ryan, and every other modern house speaker.  Furthermore, the Paris Climate agreement was largely symbolic and Obama knew that, it never had teeth and the scientists said up front it wasn't even close to addressing the scope of the problem when you actually examine the proposals.  My point is, the democrats, at least the mainstream neoliberal variety and almost just as guilty here.  In some ways they are worse because symbolically they represent the opposite of what their policies detail.  Why? They're just as bought as John McCain who within a few years does a 180 degree turn on his climate positions as shown in this video.  If we want change we will have to fight much harder for it in ways which go beyond electoral politics.

text:
There is a climate emergency: See Grand Solar Minima. If Zharkova, Abdussamatov, Soon, Easterbrook, Weiss, and others are right, its going to get too cold to grow enough food by 2030. 

We're already seeing a wilder jet stream that is steered by a weaker solar magnetic field resulting in colder winters and wilder wetter weather during the spring and fall. Nebraska lost a million calves this year. Its still too wet to plant corn in many places.
author: Ken Van de Burgt

text:
"2017 was the hottest year on record" ... its a matter of hundredths of a degree. Temperature anomaly is 0.8 C warmer than 1880 ... which marks the end of a period known as the mini ice age. Most of the temperature records were set in the 1930's; aka the dustbowl years.


Temperatures are not yet as warm as the Holocene Normal. 


Vikings used to farm in Greenland and no one is farming there now because its still too cold.
author: Ken Van de Burgt

text:
There is no evidence that rising levels of CO2 in the atmosphere pose an immediate or even an imminent threat to the climate.

Climate change is a natural cycle driven by the sun and moderated by ocean currents. Solar cycles correlate to temperature anomaly as determined from geological reconstructions for over 10000 years.

Here's to hoping carbon capture becomes viable and we reduce our emissions drastically over the next decade.

text: Just to be clear, both Climate Change and Global Warming are separate things. They are normal events that happen throughout Earth's history. The main issue is the speed of Global Warming. The ecosystems of planet Earth are not accustomed for a quick change in temperature rather a gradual one (we are talking thousands of years). However, Earth has it's own mechanisms to reduce CO2 in the environment. This is increase in it's cooling like hurricanes and storms, ocean absorption but they can do so much until they are ineffective. Another is due to Orbital positioning and Solar Minimum (Solar maximum would basically cause hotter temperatures). Last time I checked we were still in a Solar Minimum. Spring is when most of Earth's CO2 dissipates from the air. Which helps a lot in diminishing CO2 concentrations. The main problem is gases like methane and other high carbon chain gases. Though they dissipate fast, they cause heavy damage. This is where we should tackle the problem first.
author: Carlos Rodríguez

text: The IPCC is a government bureaucracy and not a scientific body of investigators.  The IPCC has been wrong in all their prognosticatians from the beginning and yet somehow they seem to keep on putting out chicken little stories.  Do some reading.  There are many scientists who do not agree with the IPCC and there is no 97% consensus about global warming.  BTW "consensus" is anti scientific as science is never settled by voting or group think.  Look at some of Tony Heller's videos. The data shows that there has been no warming of earth atmosphere as documented by the use of satellite data since 1998 and no increase in surface temperature for 15 years. Do not be duped by these charlatans. The earth had been warming for past 200 years but this is a normal variation and in fact is beneficial to life.  Cold kills more than heat. Carbon Dioxide is beneficial and essential to all life on earth. In fact we are carbon based organisms and every carbon atom in our bodies was at one time contained in a carbon dioxide molecule before it was captured by a plant and converted to a carbohydrate through photosynthesis.  Look at the carbon cycle. Its a continuous loop. Even if we stopped burning all fossil fuels there would be no measurable effect on global temperatures.  This is a fools errand.  Wise up.

text:
OF course it does. It is nasa, a political organization that only gets the big bucks for climate if it keeps pushing the alarmism. The point is, your claim that it is getting browner is a lie.

Co2 doesn't trap heat, as proven by nasa satellites in the 1990's. All of the models say that the heat leaving the planet goes down with co2, but the satellite shows it going up. Which do you think we should believe, models that can be manipulated to say anything or actual measurements?

author: Casimir

text:
You do realize that skepticalscience.com is run by a political communication professor? In other words, not only does he know how to spin a lie as the truth, but he teaches it.

The falsehood here is that they claim people are trying to say that ghg's effect does not exist. Yes, it does exist or we would not be alive. No one doubt that's. What has not been proven is the sensitivity of the atmosphere to co2 changes. Let me ATTEMPT to explain it.

By itself, with nothing else, co2 can rise the temperature about 1°C to 2°c in AN ENCLOSED ENVIRONMENT. Add water vapor, or as they do in many cases, ice, and you can easily caused the ENCLOSED ENVIRONMENT to get 3° or even 5° warmer.

BUT the atmosphere is not an enclosed environment. In order to get from the 1° to 8°c they have to add multiple POSITIVE feedbacks, and totally ignore the NEGATIVE feedbacks of the atmosphere. Lets look at one of them: clouds.

If clouds form low, they are highly reflective of sunlight. This causes MORE sunlight to be reflected back into space. In addition, low level clouds are more TRANSPARENT to infrared. So the more of energy that earth radiates is lost to space.

High level clouds are the reverse. They ABSORB more sunlight, warming the atmosphere. They are also more REFLECTIVE of infrared. That is why on a cloudy day, with high clouds, its warmer at night. They reflect the infrared the earth radiates back to the earth.

The early computer models had ever cloud high level. Even today they will admit they do not know how to model the clouds.

Another negative feedback the alarmist refuse to even consider is that co2 radiates energy into space. Every model they use shows the infrared leaving the planet being reduced as co2 goes up. Satellites from the 1990's prove the reverse. Increasing co2 means increasing infrared leaving the planet. This is a negative feedback NOT ONE of the models consider.

"for your very first claim" The falsehood here is that I did not use greenhouse data. I used satellite data.

As I said, the blogs you use are written by a professional spin doctor who knows how to spin falsehoods to sound like they are true.

text:
Denying global warming requires that one must first deny the physical science of the greenhouse effect:
Electromagnetic radiation includes Infrared Radiation (IR) and visible light. Both are absorbed by the surface of the Earth and converted to kinetic energy (heat). This heat is emitted back outward as thermal radiation aka IR. A significant amount of this IR is reabsorbed by the denser atmospheric gases such as water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, etcetera (not nitrogen and oxygen). This excites their molecular structure and the resulting kinetic energy re-emits IR. Life on Earth is made possible by the capturing of enough IR to keep the biosphere warm enough to sustain life. As the heavier molecules in the atmosphere increase, the amount of IR also increases.
‪https://samslair.blogspot.com/search?q=Greenhouse+Effect&m=1‬

How quantum mechanics explains global warming - Lieven Scheire

text: I usually respect the other side of a debate but to the arguments such as "dinosaurs lived just fine when the earth was warmer" are just so depressing to hear. If you don't know the easiest counter argument it's this. we aren't dinosaurs, neither is any other life on earth as of right now. Today's life is not adapted to the temperatures of 60 million years ago. The greenland ice sheets are losing hundreds of billions of tonnes of ice, and the antarctic ice sheets are only gaining 82 billion tonnes a year (down from 116). Humans do only contribute 3% of the carbon emissions but that 3% isn't being absorbed as the rest of it is. Just because 3 is a small number doesn't mean there is no significant impact. Yes CO2 is only a 10,000th of the atmosphere, but the zone layer is even less and it still does so much. All these arguments I hear are debunk-able with a few minutes research or basic scientific knowledge from high school. I would rather look but at this time as the time we did something about Climate Change and put aside our partisan differences, but I'm afriad I will remember it as yet another time partisan politics, fake news, and a general lack of appreciation for the facts made way for the climate to get hotter and hotter until entire countries (sounds extreme, but google it) and provinces are submerged.

You can blame Republicans for climate change all you want - Nature holds everyone (Democrats and Republicans, old and unborn, Chinese and Swedish) responsible all the same. text: Do your own research. Start with the BBC documentary:" The Great Global Warming Swindle". There is no CO2 based Global Warming. We are entering another Grand Solar Minimum, due to a 400 year cyclical period of solar inactivity, and that information has been known since the seventies. It happens every 400 years. The last one was called the Maunder Minimum, during the 1600s, and during those 75 years, the river Thames froze over every winter. And after that, the sun woke up again and things started warming up again, like it does every cycle. CO2 is plantfood, not a pollutant. Plants thrive when there is more CO2, and they make our oxygen with it. More CO2 makes more plants. And then we breathe out CO2 for them again. Pollution is a problem, toxic waste is a problem, plastic bottles are a problem. Fukushima is a problem. But nobody deals with that, because we are kept distracted with a harmless natural compound that is not a problem.

text:
Science classes are classes where you perform experiments and make conclusions based upon your ability to repeat the findings of those experiments. Basic Earth Science classes are not science classes. They are propaganda classes where you are taught what to think. 

Bottom line? CO2 increases follow the heating of the Earth, not the other way around. Need proof, here's some from a guy who will back up your argument by telling you only part of the story in order to camouflage his lie by admitting and then twisting the truth. Here you go: https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/11362

WARNING: What you'll read in the opening three paragraphs is truth mixed with nonsense, because while the Director of the Earth Science Division at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center does indeed admit that pre-industrial times show CO2 lagging the heating of the planet, he does not explain why the planet would have heated in the first place during these pre-industrial times when CO2 started out low and then climbed along with the temperature increase. 

Think about it...

If he did tell you why the Earth got warmer during those times without a preceing increase in CO2, you might just ask yourself if that same factor might be heating the Earth now as well, and that certainly wouldn't have served his purpose now would it?

The answer? Whether or not you buy into CO2 acting as a substantial greenhouse gas, we can all agree that when it comes down to it, it is the SUN that heats our planet. Unfortunately, what the scientists fail to tell the Global Warming/Climate Change believers is that when the sun throws off more solar winds, it blocks cosmic rays, which all scientists know are integral to the Earth's formation of clouds. 

Less clouds = more heat reaching the Earth = increased temperatures. Bottom line? Human production of CO2 is a tiny part of all CO2 released and is negligible when compared to CO2 released from volcanos and the natural degredation of plant particles.

The bad news is that we can't turn down the sun or alter its processes. The good news is that during Medieval Times, the Medieval Warm Period brought 300 years of added wealth and prosperity that actually resulted in a doubling of the world's population, so even if the sun doe bump up the overal temperature by a few degrees, it's going to be a boon, not a bust for the people of the Earth.

@Messiah Complex  The world will survive alright. It's just we won't be in it. All preceded by starvation, water deprivation, famine, wars and migration on unimaginable scale. My country, Great Britain, has just declared national climate emergency. What is your country doing?

The arrogance with which climate change knowledge is denied, particularly when it comes to expertise of people who devoted their entire lives to it is stunning.

No, I am not. Physics show that ice absorbs energy when it melts and holds that energy until it freezes again. The amount of heat required to melt 25 grams of ice is 8350 Joules or 2000 calories.  Greenland is suppose to be losing 269 BILLION TONS of ice. That means it is storing OVER 20 quadrillion calories. That means, just to melt the ice lost by Greenland, you have to prevent that much energy from escaping from the planet. When you add all the rest AND rise it to average ocean temperature, there is very little that is not accounted for.

Do you seriously think that adding 100's of quadrillion of calories to the ocean is not going to increase global temperature?

text: Gnome Ann I don’t follow. Where I live (north east), we see temperatures during the winter in the negatives. As for rising sea levels and everything else, there’s a large variety of attributing factors to things. “Global warming” is a generalized statement...slapping a label on something just to have a finger to point at...which is anyone in the energy business which we all know to be primarily fossil fuels. The laws of thermodynamics will show anyone that fossil fuels are, by far, the best source for energy bc of its yield for the amount of effort put in. I applaud the clean energy efforts...I truly do. Plus we would all LOVE to not have to pay big energy bills...but the jobs it provides, the benefits, the margins are far too valuable to give up or kick down and beat up. People are curb stomping their only life-blood and they don’t even realize it. Besides...what do average citizens know about carbon footprints and emissions? They hear something that sounds logical and legitimate and bc it comes from a “reputable source”, it must be true, right? Wrong...these so-called “experts” are just people trying   To understand what’s goin on the only way they know how...and I’m sure many are bought off to write articles and scientific publications to meet someone else’s specific narrative. It’s a war being waged and everyone else are pawns...made to believe something knowing it will sway voting decisions on the political battle field. It’s all propaganda. The U.S. could double our emissions and still not even begin to scratch the surface on how much China pollutes and we can’t control their actions...and that’s the tip of the iceberg. Natural occurrences such as volcanoes produce far more emissions than all humanity can conjure up in several generations. People need to reconsider what their being fed and just try to open their mind to this “global warming” stuff actually being nonsense. If average citizens want to start contributing to a cleaner environment, they should boycott energy businesses by shutting off their breakers in their house. Don’t support fossil fuels if you don’t believe in them...
author: Darius

text: @Darius  If everyone were to cut off their breakers it would be genocide to the electric providers. It doesn't have to be. Global climate as said should not be moving st the pace it is now. Yes, you may live in a place were the winter climate falls into the negatives but because it is reaching such tempuratures it's probably either not on the ocean or very far north. The places having the largest climate impact are those on the ocean in moderate or high climates. They are seeing heat records being broken time over time and it seems like the next year it's gonna be hotter. And the ocean is even worse. It is estimated that if all the ice were to melt, it could happen by 2070 at most and would plunge all of our beaches 50 metres under water. And the more heat in the ocean the worse hurricanes there will be, and the more that will occur which will cause many billions and trilions of dollars of damage. 50 metres under water? Tens and maybe hundreds of trillions in damage and over two billion people will be homeless. Think about how many refugees that is. And world wide famine would occur because our most common crops cannot handle climate change. Not much and definantly not enough. Is this worth continuing with a slowely dying economic sector? How will you feel knowing that people like you caused our ultimate fate and billions of dead people.
author: Ashton Bull

text:
Ashton Bull again, that’s pointing the finger at fossil fuels/the energy industry. Just bc you hear the propaganda doesn’t make it true. Those who are actually believing in that nonsense, want to believe it and swear they know it to be gospel bc some panel of experts they never met before said it to be what’s to blame.
Also...consider this. Who are we to control what happens? Whether we are to blame for climate change or not, who are we to try to manipulate that in any way. We could have such a profound effect on the eco system, it could cause detrimental damage by just trying to control it. How would THAT make you feel...especially if you found out it was all bullshit to begin with? Not so good, right? The argument could be made both ways. We aren’t god and we were never meant to control something so large and so natural and something we can’t begin to understand. Besides...humans aren’t effecting global warming. You clearly read my last reply. People aren’t even aware of how little our emissions are and that there’s no possible way we are to blame for temperatures rising. That’s fact. You can read up on it if you so choose. There’s plenty of literature to counter global warming if you care to take the time and see what the OTHER “experts” have to say.
In addition to all this, the last I recall, the earth always did what it wanted and always will. You don’t control Mother Nature, I controls you. It will change and evolve. You can most certainly bet your last dollar on that...but just as any species (including and especially humans) Had to live accordingly to weather climates and water levels. They had to move. They had to migrate. It’s unfortunate and inconvenient thing to have to resort to...but don’t you believe it’s a little bit arrogant to complain about what nature is doing? As if...how dare Mother Nature change on us like this. We don’t manipulate that. If water levels are rising, either you cope with it or you get out of dodge. You don’t get to make that decision. Mother Nature makes it for you.  It’s arrogant to think that we can dictate what is suppose to happen. Earthquakes happen. Lives are lost. Hurricanes happen...lives are lost. Sink holes happen...lives are lost. It’s inevitable and it always will be. It comes with the territory of living and being on planet earth. It’s horrible sometimes but that’s why many of us choose not to live in those highly active regions and coast lines. We don’t want those issues...but if we had to, we would move...naturally...bc that’s what common sense tells you when ur in a bad situation.

text: CO2 is a greenhouse gas. That is it both absorbs and releases infrared photons. Once released, there is one chance in 41,253 that infrared photon will continue within one degree in the same direction. This basically gives that photon a 50/50 chance of going either up or down. Since the oceans cover about 71% of the Earth's surface, this gives that photon about a 35% chance of hitting a body of water. Infrared photons will not penetrate a body of water's surface, but will instead excite an H2O molecule causing evaporation. H2O is the primary greenhouse gas which prevents the Earth from having a climate like our moon. Consequently, the more CO2 we put into the atmosphere, the more H2O gets into the atmosphere, the warmer the planet gets. This is how a 40% increase in CO2 caused a 7% increase in absolute humidity.  The present increase in temperature due to this combination of additional  H2O and CO2 in the atmosphere is approximately .9C at present.  Because it takes a tremendous amount of time for the oceans to heat, it will take centuries for the Earth to reach temperature equilibrium. If we continue to inject 35 gigatonnes annually of CO2 into the atmosphere, that heating process will continue to accelerate.

text:
As the atmosphere warms, the differential temperature decreases between the ocean's surface and the atmosphere, blocking the ocean from releasing its heat. That is where 93% of the additional heat is being stored. This additional heat in the oceans will not only melt the ice caps but will allow vastly larger hurricanes to form and travel at much greater distances.  The imminent threat isn't sea level rise but a future of massive storm surges. This website gives a more detailed explanation. 
https://www.skepticalscience.com/How-Increasing-Carbon-Dioxide-Heats-The-Ocean.html
author: EF M

text:
Since there seems to be an issue with fossil fuels, the question is what to do about it. This is my answer. If anyone has a different solution, I'd like to hear it. Let's begin with BTU in vs BTUs out by the energy source. 
Corn 1.3 
Solar PV 9 
Natural gas 10 
Windmills 18 
Light Water Reactors 80 
Coal 80 
Hydropower 100 
LFTR and TWR 2,000 

Now, consider deaths per terrawatt. 
Coal 161 
Oil 36 
Biomass 12 
Peat 12 
Natural gas 4 
Solar PV .44 
Hydropower .10 
Light water reactors .04 
LFTR and TWR .003 
As you can see LFTRs and TWRs are the most cost efficient and safest energy supply possible at this time. We should easily be able to reach $0.02 to $0.03 per kilowatt-hour. That brings the price of everything down substantially. Building small mass-produced modular breeder reactors would also make windmills and solar panels exceptionally cost-effective. We could have the population producing the majority of their own energy leaving nuclear energy for industry. Or we can continue with this absurd global warming debate.
author: EF M

text: Let us now talk about the multiplier effect. If we build breeder reactors first and use that electricity to produce solar panels, the BTU multiplier effect would be 2000*9=18,000 to 1. Considering a coal-fired power plant has a ratio of about 80 to 1, that figures out to be about 18,000/80=225 times the increase in efficiency. Doing so would flatten out the hierarchies of the world, creating vastly greater independence worldwide. This would accomplish exactly what the murderous communists attempted but badly failed at.
author: EF M

text:
LOCKBOX...What an idiot. Solar activity fluctuates in an 11-year cycle. But so far in this cycle, the sun has been disturbingly quiet. The lack of increased activity could signal the beginning of what is known as a Maunder Minimum, an event which occurs every couple of centuries and can last as long as a century. 
Such an event occurred in the 17th century. The observation of sunspots showed extraordinarily low levels of magnetism on the sun, with little or no 11-year cycle. 
This solar hibernation corresponded with a period of bitter cold that began around 1650 and lasted, with intermittent spikes of warming, until 1715. Frigid winters and cold summers during that period led to massive crop failures, famine and death in Northern Europe.
Tapping reports no change in the sun's magnetic field so far this cycle and warns that if the sun remains quiet for another year or two, it may indicate a repeat of that period of drastic cooling of the Earth, bringing massive snowfall and severe weather to the Northern Hemisphere.

text:
Hey, there’s a easy fix to this, and while it’s not yet been tested on how it will affect the ozone layer, there’s really no downside to it. All we have to do is pump sulfur into the  atmosphere. It sounds crazy, but when you put sulfur into gas form, its got the ideal density for the ozone layer. All you need to do is find the hole, get a massive tube, tie a  weather  balloon to it, and start pumping sulfur. And we have enough sulfur to do it too. Sulfur gas is the primary gas waste that comes out of mining, and the amount of sulfur Canada and America alone pumps out is more than enough. It’s really that easy. Just a year or two to make sure sulfur doesn’t have a destructive reaction to the ozone layer’s gases, and that’s it. 

Now why isn’t anyone doing this? Ir’s Because  artificially  stabilizing a planet’s  atmosphere is the first step to  artificially engineering our planet. And people can’t seem to figure out Thad you can only do so much damage to something before they can’t heal by themselves. When an organ fails, we replace it. When a person gets burned to the bone, you  artificially insert new skin. When an action figure’s arm falls off, you don’t put them next to each other and hope they  reconnect, you glue it back on! Earth is like that action figure,  we’ve damaged it too much to simply wait for it to heal, we need to take responsibility as the host, and fix what we broke.

text: Weather station/monitoring data is public. Climate is not just the moving temperature average but also seasonal temperatures, rainfall, temperature-volatility, irregular freezing in spring or autumn, greenhouse gases and ocean currents. Weather is the day-to-day temperature and rainfall instead of the long-term trends and volatility. I agree that it's warm in the summer and cold in the winter, but these peaks and lows aren't the same every year. Especially since we hit existentially-threatening 400ppm CO2 levels that threaten the runaway feedback loop of increasing temperatures and relative humidity, water vapor, and desertification. Even with the ice sheets melting and the oceans absorbing the majority of CO2, we are still seeing cataclysmic disaster on a global scale, while it's still reversible through drastic emergency cuts to emissions and reforestation & carbon sequestration initiatives.

author: Kanglar

text:
@Jon Hanson  
"The climate is a cycle"
Sure, but let me tell you why current climate change is a real problem since it's evident you know nothing about the subject. The problem is not "that the climate is changing", the problem is the RATE at which we see the climate changing. Sure a past extinction event could have been caused, and likely was caused, by global warming that made the Earth much hotter than it is today. But that change ramped up over a period of hundreds of thousands of years, a very quick change on the geologic time scale. The change we are seeing now is orders of magnitude faster than anything in the past, which means it's likely to cause an avalanche effect with all the positive feedback for a warming Earth once it starts, which it has. 

It's a classic example of an under damped system with positive feedback, in other words if we stopped ALL C02 emissions TODAY, we would still have Earth continuing to warm for hundreds if not thousands of years based on the past 150 years of emissions alone. I'm sure you've seen the chart of the warmest decade on record being the past 10 years; that's the climate just now catching up to about the first couple decades of emissions at the beginning of the industrial revolution. That's why our emissions today are such a big problem.

text:
" the problem is the RATE at which we see the climate changing" How do you know the climate is changing faster than it should? Is it warming faster? It has warmed .9°C in the last 100 years. In the mid 1600's, it warmed 1° in 50 years. According to proxies it has actually cooled since 1950. https://www.google.com/search?biw=1189&bih=546&tbm=isch&sa=1&ei=OBAMXIqqDc2OtQXtnKW4Bg&q=temperature+over+the+last+1000+years&oq=temperature+over+the+last+1000+years&gs_l=img.3..0i7i30j0i7i5i30l2j0i5i30.80670.80670..81389...0.0..0.96.96.1......1....1..gws-wiz-img.yM4_DGkOtvw#imgrc=aSEmk0NJey121M:&spf=1544294540391

So where is the increased rate of increase?

"Sure a past extinction event could have been caused, and likely was caused, by global warming that made the Earth much hotter than it is today." So where is the evidence of it? At no point is there any evidence that global warming caused an extinction.

There has been 5 great extinction event, all of them blamed by alarmist on co2. 1 just happen to coincide with the earth being stuck by an asteroid that burned off a large portion of the worlds trees. Alarmist point out the sudden increase in co2 and say that was what killed the animals, but ignore the fact that it was briefly exceedingly hot and then suddenly cold for a long time. They ignore the fact that o2 dropped drastically.

A second was blamed on the co2 put out by a volcano that erupted for over a million years, but they ignore the fact that the point that the life died was a relatively small period where o2 dropped drastically and methane skyrocketed, due to that volcano briefly emitting a lot of nickel that fed a microbe that created methane out of co2, water and o2. The oxygen dropped below the level that most of the animals needed to survive, but the alarmist do not consider this a reason for the die off.

This pattern follows for the other three events. Alarmist blame it on co2, but ignore other causes. For instance the break up of Pangea caused a lot of environments to drastically change rapidly, killing off animals that evolved in those environments. YET alarmist blame it on the co2 increase.

"The change we are seeing now is orders of magnitude faster than anything in the past, " Thousands of years ago, it warmed 5° in only a couple centuries. It did not cause an extinction level event. In fact life bloomed after it. How is the .9°C a drastic enough change to risk anything.

"we would still have Earth continuing to warm for hundreds if not thousands of years based on the past 150 years of emissions alone." That flies in the face of history facts. At no point does an increase in co2 last long in history and there is no point where an animal like humans have caused an increase to determine that.

The biggest problem is that the model all depend on high atmospheric sensitivity to create these false hoods and history shows the sensitivity is low.

"I'm sure you've seen the chart of the warmest decade on record being the past 10 years;" The assumption here is that just because its warmer, it has to be caused by co2. Evidence says otherwise.

text:
Several years ago, the alarmist did a poll that one of their responses was "do you think we should do everything in our power no matter what the cost to stop co2". At the time, this did not make sense, since no one was proposing more than spending a few billions to finance things to remove co2. Because they limited it to only those that believed age, 96% said yes. Then the Paris accord came out and the US alone was suppose to spend 3 BILLION dollars a year to support UN programs for global warming AND the UN had the right, according to the agreement, to demand more. This was ON TOP of the US spending many more billions on green energy, something many people do not realize. They think it was ONLY the 6 billion and most do not even realize it was only for the first 2 years.

Then AOC, announced the new green deal and quoted that poll saying that all scientist believe we should do everything in our power to stop agw.

So NOW we know what "no matter the cost" means. It means the destruction of the American way of life.

"I find this tremendously curious when the vast majority of climate scientists" The fact is, the vast majority of climate scientist do not support agw. ONLY those that are accepted by the climate mafia are counted as climate scientist when they do the poll. Their limiting factor was to be published in a magazine that was controlled by the climate mafia, so of course those that were counted in that survey did support. BUT if you ask the people that are trained as scientist by an accredited university or college, and have worked as a scientist in the field, you find those that agree are in the minority. The majority 54% say there is no danger from co2. 22% say we should do everything no matter what the cost, to stop it. The rest say either we should do something, or they don't know.

"The scientific method! " Do you have any idea what the scientific method is?
1) You use the same method of measurement from beginning to end. Agw refuses to do so. Since they do not have instrument readings from more than 200 years ago, and only have good measurements since the advent of satellites THAT is as far back as those readings can be used. Since they need to prove that the last 200 years are unusual, they have to use proxies. IF you use proxies all the way to the end, we have not had unusual climates. There are indications that specific years of the 1000 years ago was  higher than the instruments readings of recent years, but it can not be proven.

2) In proper scientific procedure you have to show EVERYTHING you do. People like Michael Mann still hide their data. EVEN NASA, refuses to show how they adjust their data.

3). When  you are publish data, you are suppose to be reviewed by your scientific peers. Climatologist say that no one else can possibly understand because their field covers a lot of area, but that is just a way to limit the number of people that can review their work.4) Agw is a theory. If a theory is shown to have holes in it, in proper scientific standards, it would be withdrawn and reworked to include all the new data, or dismissed. AGW proponents REFUSE to do so. They double down and demand that their theory be totally disproven or accepted as a law. Sceptics are not suppose to have to disprove it, only to show the holes.

"Fermi Paradox" Well, I wasn't going to point out the similarities between people that believed in agw and those that believe aliens walk among us, but....:)

The reality is, alarmist insist on ignoring all the evidence to the contrary, and demand their theory be accepted as law, despite the fact is has such huge holes.

author: robert hicks

text:
@bluegold21  I have been paying attention to the fake logic of man made global cooling/warming/climate change/dramatic weather changes for over 50 years. When I was a kid, the area I grew up had several years where the winters got so cold we had to have snow days. Now, they dont have them any more. I was told this happen 60 years before, but they had not had to have them in decades.

IF im being paid, I want to talk to someone, as I havent gotten any paychecks.

What I have also been paying attention so is so many of their predictions are failing. 

They said by 2005, there would be food riots and people would be resorting to cannibalism because of the heat killing off the cattle and plants. Instead the increase in co2 has caused a 16% increase in food production. 

They originally said that the polar ice caps would melt by 1995, and when they didnt, they moved the goal post to 2005, then 2013, 2017, and now 2020.

They said that Miami and New York would be flooded by 2005, yet 13 years later, they have barely lost any land to the sea.

I have read the IPCC reports and its obvious that there are lots of lies. For instance, the 97% consensus was first reported by IPCC as being created by a tenured professor who had worked in the climate field for 27 year, but it turned out to have been written by a 22 year old POLITICAL SCIENCE student that flunked out of college. When that happened, several other POLITICAL science students and professors replicated his work using slightly more accurate results. Not one of them has ever been more than 10% accurate. They are all filed with 90% lies at least.

If my "betters" come looking for me, they better bring plenty of weapons. As a USAF vet, I know a lot about warfare and as someone trained in non standard weapons and tactics, they better hope they know more about it than I do.

The future is not that of a wasteland, and certainly not because of co2. The wasteland is the minds of those that cant think for themselves and can only beg people like Al Gore to protect them by taking all their money. Dont come to me when you are broke because the liberals took all your rights because your too terrified of the boogeymen that dont even exist.
author: robert hicks

text:
robert hicks it looks like you never read any climate report by looking what you wrote...so let’s talk about it.


You said that scientists predicted by 2005 that there would be food riots and cannibalism...unfortunately, especially the cannibalist part, no scientist ever said that. When they talk about climate change causing droughts (maybe you were referring to that) they were pretty spot on... not even talking about all the terrible droughts in california or australia or africa especially, by looking at the datas the surface of the sahara desert increased by over a million square kilometers from 1970 to 2000.
The past century has already seen drought severity increase in places like the Mediterranean, southern Africa, and the eastern coast of Australia.  So Its already happening. But referring to the 16% food productivity increase I literally searched everywhere and I found no evidence on that data because the only studies about the link between CO2 levels and food growth where all projections and not actual calculations. Its true that an increase of CO2 can increase vegetable growth but its just a very reductive point of view: you have to include the influence of water evaporization, of the higher number of floods and droughts and especially of the region you are taking in consideration. For example in tropical regions cause of higher temperatures the plants growth decrease by over 50% instead in a region like europe crops can increase their growth by 13%. 

On the other point it depends on what study or organization you were referring to.... you can’t just say “they said that polar ice caps were totally melting by 1995” because who is they? Not even today any scientific organization predicted that polar ice caps will be totally gone by 2020.... and also are you referring to just artic Ice pole? Or also antartica? Or both of them? And you are considering the entire year or only summer? You can believe everything you want but scientists predicted that the coverage of ice in both artic and antartic were going to decrease significantly and in fact this is what is already happening. Oh and the north pole is nearly ice free during summer there is a reason why russia and other countries are pushing to invest in that region because now they can.

“They said that miami and new york would be flooded by 2005” again I didn’t find any report asserting that but Miami saw an increase of sea levels equal to five inches and new york sea levels raised by 275% since 2000 (9 inches growth) and thats A LOT. You just have to look on what is happening in many parts of miami where now is literally normal that they get flooded even when it doesn’t rain. 

And its also clear that you never read the IPCC reports because they NEVER wrote about the 97% consensus lol. They didn’t reported the study and they didn’t fund it. And I really don’t know who you are referring to when you talked about the 22 year old political science...also because the study that was published was made by a team not a single person. But if you really think that the ipcc is lying you should look up at their reports since the first one in 1990 because they predicted results that were pretty close on what really happened.
author: Carosello Show

text:
@Carosello Show  So you agree that James Hansen is not a scientist? He is the one that said we would have cannibalism by 2005.

"When they talk about climate change causing droughts (maybe you were referring to that) they were pretty spot on." Quite the contrary. IF anything they are fewer. https://goo.gl/images/3Yvhv8 here is england results. 
Here is the alarmist own view of it. show me where droughts are getting worse. https://goo.gl/images/nTuvgV
Here is one from canada. Again,  increasing temperature does not cause worse drought. http://pcag.uwinnipeg.ca/Prairie-Perspectives/PP-Vol02/mcginn-bryant.pdf

The only reason that drought SEEM worse is the news reports them now as 100 years ago, if  you heard about them it was months later.

Even the Sahara desert is NOT getting worse. https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamestaylor/2012/10/25/contrary-to-what-you-hear-global-warming-has-been-good-to-africa/#343985b427f6 Satellites have shown that it is greener in the last 30 years due to co2 increase.

"The past century has already seen drought severity increase in places like the Mediterranean, southern Africa, and the eastern coast of Australia." The increases in "drought severity" is in fact not due to increases in co2, but failure to take care of the land. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-4OBcRHX1Bc
The truth is, in an attempt to increase the food the land produces, people are getting rid of things like willow trees and preventing the water from standing on the land. The result is that the land dries out. Many places have channeled rivers or flood plains trying to make them carry more food. The result is the land doesnt have the water to grow the food.

" because who is they?" James Hansen, the first IPCC, and groups like that.

"the coverage of ice in both artic and antartic were going to decrease significantly and in fact this is what is already happening. " Quite the contrary. While ice is disappearing in the north, its increasing the same amount in the south. Its not disappearing, its moving from one pole to the other. I would love to have you show me the satellite graph of the ice in Antarctica disappearing. Several years ago, someone tried to do so, but as someone trained by the USAF, I immediately saw the lie of what they said. The NASA blog said it was disappearing, but the graph did not show what he said it did. The graph showed increases of 1-3 inches per year as light green, increases of more as dark green, and decreases in red similarly. There was a good bit more dark red than dark green, which is where they got their claim, BUT the dark red showing 3-10 inches of decrease were tiny compared to the area increase. Perhaps 2% of the map showed a decrease, while 90% showed an increase (about 5-7% showed no change) Even if the entirety of the decreasing area was the full 10 inches (not likely) and even if the 90% only had 1 inch (not likely), you still had more than snow falling each year than disappearing.

After I pointed this out, the graph and the blog both disappeared from NASA site. I cant find any place that still has the graph.

" Miami saw an increase of sea levels equal to five inches and new york sea levels raised by 275% since 2000 (9 inches growth) and thats A LOT." Water does not build up in one spot. It finds the same level. So why is New York and Miami seeing a lot more change instead? The answer is subsidence. https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/glacial-adjustment.html All the east coast (New York and Boston) are sinking as the magma beneath them moves towards Canada and Ohio, where the glaciers were 15000 year ago. Miami was built on top of a brimy aquifer. They could not drink it but they drained a swamp feeding it. Thus they emptied it and the land settled. It has caused an increase in subsidence of 3 mm a year. That is over half the increase they have seen in Miami. http://www.ces.fau.edu/arctic-florida/pdfs/fiaschi-wdowinski.pdf

In addition, it has been know for over a century that there is an Atlantic oscillation. What this means is that there  is a 60 year wave that goes back and forth across the Atlantic. For 30 year, one side will get an increase in sea level while the other side will see a decrease. For the last 20 years years the water has been moving west, so it shows an increase in New York and Miami. In 10 year, that will reverse and the water will move towards Europe and England. This increase is most of the last half of what Miami is seeing. This does not mean there is not an increase in sea level. World wide has seen an increase of about 6 inches over the last century. This is the result of glaciers melting.

"the IPCC reports because they NEVER wrote about the 97% consensus" The very first one did. They removed it after it was proven that the person that wrote the report was NOT a tenured professor and someone that had worked in the field for 25 years as they claimed, but was in fact a 22 year old student in political science who flunked out because he deliberately lied about his report.

"because the study that was published was made by a team not a single person." The first three reports were all done by single people. Only later ones were done by groups and that does not mean they were any  better, considering that every one was from a course in political communication, what laymen call spin doctoring.

text:
So your saying that when the planet was 28°C 70 million years ago, plants could not grow? The entire planet was alive with life, almost no deserts existed if any at all. The only reasons we have deserts is the world is too cold. As temperatures and co2 go up deserts shrink. The reason is there is more moisture in the air and that means more rain. More rain means more water for plants. More co2 means they can hold the water better.

Greenhouses keeps their plants warmer to encourage them to grow, so your theory that hotter temperatures will cause them to die is wrong.

10000 years ago, the temperatures were hotter than they are now, and yet the Sahara was a garden, as was the American southwest deserts. I have never heard anything about the other deserts, except for Antarctica, I suspect most of them had more growth.

author: Salomao Serra

text:
Allow me to throw a little bit of facts on your fire. 1) For the majority of earth's history, the temperature was 26°c. Most of the time it wasn't, it was 11°c The rest of the time it floated between 28° and 11°. Currently we are 14.5°. That's 3°C above the coldest the planet has ever been.
2) We are in an ice age, created by Antarctica and the Himalayan mountains freezing over. Unless you move those two, the temperature can not climb more than 3°C hotter than it is now. That is because of the earths albedo. There is so much ice and snow on the planet that it is reflecting a large portion of the suns energy back into space.
3) when both of those areas froze, the co2 levels were at 1500 ppm. How can the co2 increasing from 350 to 410 cause them to melt? EVEN if as the scientist predict, the co2 goes to 750 by 2100, it will not be more than half of what the atmosphere  held when those froze. The most that increasing co2 that much would do is raise it by 3°c because that is the limit that the albedo creates. That is not sufficient to melt the ice in the world.
author: robert hicks

text:
Deserts were not created by erosion. They were caused by the cold.

Your claim that it does not increase rain goes counter to all science, including history.

The truth is, hurricanes are at a slight (albeit statistically insignificantly) decrease in number and intensity over the last 50 years. Tornados are most definitely decrease, especially in the upper intensity range. Droughts are a small fraction of what they were during little ice age, and even have decreased in the last 100 years.

So, no it does not make it worse.

text:
I know your comment is 1 year old, but pollution isn't specific to capitalism.  

Simply look at what the USSR did to the Aral sea or to all the nuclear pollution in ex-Soviet republics.  Pollution is due to our overconsumption, not to the economic system in place, knowing that non-capitalist economic systems doesn't mean that we won't overproduce stuff. 

Everything will change when all individuals, include you and I, will change the way we live.  We need to buy less, but also to make choices that have smaller impacts on the environment (example: stop buying big 4x4 SUVs with big engines and buy smaller cars or stop wasting 1/4 of the food we buy).  Then, since we're in a capitalist economy, the market will simply readapt itself to the new demands of consumers.  Yes, many companies will go bankrupt and this will cause many economic problems, but the capitalist economy will always readapt itself to the new supply and demand.

text:
Livestock production accounts for 70 per cent of all agricultural land use, occupies 30 per cent of the planet’s land surface and is responsible for 18 per cent of greenhouse gases such as methane and nitrous oxide.
Growing animals for food is also inefficient. It takes about five to seven kilograms of grain to produce one kilogram of beef. Each of those takes energy and water to produce, process, and transport. As global meat consumption increases, so does its climate impact.

text:
Wow, this is extremely misleading, shame on you. You present the appearance of a bipartisan consensus on climate change that ended during the Obama administration. This never happened. The republican party has had a consistent do-nothing policy on climate change since the Bush administration. These clips of republicans endorsing mitigation of climate change are mostly campaign-trail attempts at swaying democrats and independents to vote for them. They didn't actually plan on implementing policy, quite the opposite. This is some weird propaganda - you seem to think that republicans flipping on the climate issue appears worse than being consistent science-denying plutocrats. 

I like your usual content, but this is lazy and borderline misinformation.

text:
republicans know climate change is real .they just don't care .they probably have insurance up the wazoo .republicans don't believe americans have the right to clean air and water .what does that tell you about them ? they use word salads to describe their policies . they say things like ,we have to make common sense decisions or tough decisions .then there is this little word deception .coming to a neighborhood near you ......................Senate Bill 652, cunningly known as the Critical Infrastructure Protection Act, is part of a coordinated, nationwide campaign by the oil and gas industry to shield itself from any accountability for the pipelines, drilling rigs, and other projects they’re putting on your farms, in your backyards, near your schools, or close to your communities. 
The goal of SB 652 is straightforward: to frighten Pennsylvanians away from opposing oil and gas projects, even if they will harm our health, land, or families. The bill's sole existence is fundamentally at odds with the core tenets of our democracy.
SB 652 defines 21 categories of private facilities, including pipeline and gas processing plants, as “critical infrastructure facilities.” The bill would make it a felony of the first or second degree if any person enters onto the property of such a facility with the intent of “impeding or inhibiting” operations.  Under current law, it’s considered a summary or misdemeanor offense. The proposed change also makes liable persons who conspired to engage in the prohibited conduct. This means a person who attended a meeting during which a peaceful protest was planned against construction of an oil and gas facility could also be prosecuted for committing a felony - the same grade of offense used to define capital murder.
 
Please OPPOSE this attack on the rights of Pennsylvanians to stand up for their clean air and clean water. This is an attempt to silence Pennsylvanians who oppose environmental degradation, the potential consequences of natural gas infrastructure, and the reckless behavior of the oil and gas industry.

text:
To all who has disliked this video and all who will dislike this video, I totally understand if Vox is not your number one news site that you trust. Of course we all have our preferences for the news and incidents where news outlets purposely skew some news events for their own agenda have made people skeptical. 


However, if you disliked this video not for which site displays this content but for the content itself, then think about this. 

There has been a trend in global disasters occurring. All over the world, temperatures are getting hotter, sea levels are getting higher, rain has been getting heavier. More and more natural disasters have been devastating our earth, and even those against climate change can't deny we are seeing these natural disasters not only more frequently, but more quickly too. 

If you don't trust numbers generated and/or agreed upon by 98% of the world's scientists, trust the anguished cries of those trapped by natural disasters. 

Trust the grief of those who have lost someone in a natural disasters, regardless of where it has happened. Trust the billions of dollars lost because we don't take a stand against emitting carbon dioxide gases that are warming our planet and making that one child in California lose all he or she knows on a devastating forest fire. Trust the exhaustion of so many rescue workers who have to see the same scene over and over again because we are too busy trying to denounce each other's political ideologies and bickering amongst ourselves to even CARE. 

People all around the world are TIRED of having to deal with their family members dying everyday. So why aren't we doing anything??

It won't take much for us to do anything, and it definitely shouldn't be just governments doing anything. But if governments, the institutions we rely on to govern our lives, refuse to do anything significant to help anyone, to stop what's been happening in Laos or Indonesia or Thailand or California from happening to anyone else, then when will we? 

Climate change is not a theory, or a scientific hypothesis waiting for someone to prove it and be awarded a Nobel Prize for. It is something that is happening every single second we live on this earth.

text:
Azrael If what I heard from the news and other sources is correct, it is not as simple as that anymore. What you ask was possible YEARS back. Some reports say that it can cost up to $50 trillion when it is all over with. 
Then again, I think it depends on what one believes. Are the reports exaggerating a lot? Maybe a bit? Not at all? They say that we have less than 15 years. Can the whole world change just like that within 15 years? 
When something negative happens within an industry or a sector of an economy, it has a knock-on effect on the rest of it. You can't just gut certain parts and expect for it to be ok. 
I am all in favor of renewables. I recycle plenty. I hope to get myself a Tesla when I begin working after graduating from college and saving a bit of money. I am drawn to the e-bikes, but I live in a large city and just by car it can take me 30 minutes or so to get to places. 
Will that be enough? If the entire US went green will that be enough? What about the rapidly industrializing countries of China and India?
author: Sir Xi Gutierrez von Wallenstein VI

text: Here in the Philippines, we know global warming is happening. It's not a myth. Every year, summers become hotter. Typhoons are stronger and are becoming very common. Areas which were never hystorical pathways of typhoons are now experiencing them in  a regular basis. We experience it, we feel it. Just because you don't believe it happening because you are not in vulnerable areas doesn't mean that it is not real. I was born in the 90's and I remember quite well that it was much cooler back then. I could play outside with friends and never worry about the heat of the sun early in the morning. Now, even early mornings feel like noontime. Please don't deny that it is not happening. We experience it here.

text:
You need solid incentives to drive human greed. A carbon emmision tax, higher taxes on meat for consumers , financed solar pannels installation or special loans to homeowners so they can cover the big initial investement.
 Only if all the money is flowing to "green" firms, and they are growing, and distributing juicy utilities, and they develop their own lobby power. Only if the big superpowers are racing between themselves to be completly self sufficent using renewable energy, even if they only do it for geopolitical reasons, things can change in time.

Here is how we stop climate change.
1. Invest in GMO research to allow for higher yield, low maintenance crops. A lot of GHG's actually come from agriculture. GMO crops could require less water, and GMO feeds could be better for livestock, which also produce GHG's.
2. Gradually replace coal-fired plants with nuclear and natural gas. The renewables like wind and solar are nice, but are auxiliary sources, not primary sources of energy. Actually, we could become the world's exporter of nuclear reactors and fuel, which could be a huge boon to the economy.
3.  Massively increase the extraction of natural gas, this should come to replace oil as our primary energy export. Natural gas is WAY cleaner than oil and coal.
4. Plant more trees. In fact, encourage more forestry operations in the otherwise unused land. We have the tech to reclaim desert and arid land and make it arable, we should use the land for tree farms and other forms of forestry. Such technology has been proven in Spain, lets use it in the US. 

Unfortunately, most environmentalists are against natural gas, nuclear energy and GMO crops. Ironic, given that they could significantly reduce emissions.

text:
Environmentalist here.

Natural Gas is what a lot of environmentalists call a middle ground of some sorts. It's much cleaner and better chan coal or oil, but it still has a lot of environmental concerns. Natural Gas still causes emissions even if it is a lesser amount. Fracking is also believed to do a lot of local damage, notably to water supplies and leads to more earthquakes. Nucleur, Solar, Wind, etc. are much more environmental friendly.

Most environmentalists dont have as big of an issue with nuclear energy. It's much more safe than what we do now, but thorium is not a renewable energy resource, while solar and wind energy are. Thats why many of us prefer to 'skip' nuclear and jump to renewable energy.

And certain GMOs are not environmentally friendly. Specifically ones that have pesticides implemented, those seriously damage the local wildlife. GMO crops are something important and we should use them, but we should be environmentally aware of the issues with it.
author: Duck Hunt Trash

text:
+Duck Hunt Trash
Wind and solar are generally supplementary power sources. The problem with solar and wind is that they pretty much are forced to run at 100% capacity due to how they operate (a windwills power output is dictated by the wind, not the operator, same with solar panels). This causes problems with scalability. If your wind farm has 10 mills, generates 50mW, and the power consumption increases to 52mW, you now have to construct a new mill. So now our farm has 11 mills, and 55mW of output, but only 52mW of consumption, so 3mW are being wasted.

In the case of a traditional fission power plant (or any other power plant for that matter), the output can be adjusted by the operators. If my power plant has a maximum output of 100mW (at 100%), but the requirement is only 50mW, then the operators can limit output to 50% (50mW), no power is wasted in this case. If the requirement increases to 60mW, then the output limit can be adjusted to 60% (60mW). Again, no energy is lost, as energy output is controlled by the operator, not by natural forces. Because standard plants maximum capacity is typically significantly higher than the demand, they are able to easily react to increases in demand, without energy loss. Since output can be changed on the fly, as opposed to installing new panels or mills, the costs of increasing output are also much lower than standard renewables. Furthermore, since operations are centralized, maintenance is easier. This is the advantage of traditional power over renewables. Renewables are still useful. They provide very cheap power, and for areas with low power demands, such as suburban or rural areas, they are superior to standard plants. For large metropolitan areas or areas with heavy industry, power requirements are immense and fluctuate, so standard power plants are preferable in those cases. 

Now, let's not forget about Hydroelectric! Hydro actually has all the benefits of traditional plants without the drawbacks of other renewables. The only tradeoff is that construction and operation costs are staggering compared to other sources of energy. 

Now as for nuclear energy being non-renewable, I actually disagree. It's technically non-renewable, but it's about the most renewable non-renewable source of energy. Nuclear fuel can be reused and recycled quite a number of times before becoming totally useless. Disposal of spent fuel is non-trivial. Literally, just dig in a salt-rich mountain (ie somewhere out in the middle of Nevada), throw the fuel into the hole and forget about it. The salt provides radiation shielding, and desolate and arid climate will prevent potential leakages due to erosion.

For the US, due to our massive power consumption, I propose that about 40% of generation be Nuclear, 30% be Hydroelectric, and the rest be Solar, Wind, and Geothermal. With this model, our energy sector would emit no carbon, and still provide huge amounts of energy. Some smaller nations, like in Europe, could get away with almost 90% being purely hydroelectric. Those nations have some very large rivers and generally, have smaller populations with lower power requirements.

text: With the already visible effects of climate change it boggles the mind how many people still cling to the notion that petroleum is the best energy source for us to be using. I don't recall reading about any riots by the makers of the steam engine when the gas engine came along. The age of electric is now. We will be forced to switch eventually, it makes no sense not do do it now while it can still make a difference. Do you really need that Range Rover that pollutes our children air twice as much as the average car? Seriously, is it really worth it? If your ego is so fragile that you need to show your wealth there are countless ways to do it that are not bad for the environment.Theres nothing cool about leaving a future of wildfires, smoke and drought for our children. Nor intelligent. Cool is actually caring for this Earth that gives us literally every single thing we can touch. Intelligence is not buying gas guzzling SUVs and being an actual example to your children on helping protect the Earth. The idea we still drive gas powered cars is crazy, but we don't just drive cars, the SUV is the most popular vehicle in the US, we drive the biggest pieces of metal we can buy, and we don't just buy these big cars and pack them full of people, that would start being more efficient. No, we buy V8 SUVs and usually we are a single driver with maybe a couple bags of groceries. We are so off base in so many ways as far as how we need to live more practical lives, that the grains of sand are literally slipping through our fingers. If you put a frog in hot water, it jumps out. If you put it in cold water and turn the heat on, it will boil to death before it tries to jump out. We are like the frogs, and the climate deniers who want still more proof are seeking the boiling water, but for some reason they cant seem to realize by then it will be too late and whatever contribution they were planning on making will be useless.

Such a shame we can't get everyone in a room with a charismatic teacher for a few hours to 1) help them unlearn their assumption that the consensus on climate change science is based merely on pattern recognition and 2) walk them step by step through the fundamentals of molecule-scale thermodynamics that explains why carbon dioxide, methane, and water can create a greenhouse effect, the carbon cycle, and the solar system-scale energy budgets and flows that make even modest adjustments in the atmospheric chemistry of our open-system climate incredibly important.
edit Oh, and it would be fantastic if we could enroll the entirety of the population, or at least Congress, in a glaciology course, because 1) they're really fun and cool and 2) because spending 20 minutes in a glaciology class was enough time for me to realize that no one understands glaciers and how complex they are and how important they are to our climate.

text: You might want to consider what's going on in China and India, they are the biggest threat to rising CO2 levels.  The USA is responsible for just 13% of the world CO2 emissions while China is 26% and expected to grow a lot more until 2030. If solar and wind were competitive with fossil fuels you would see China and India building a majority of power plants being solar and wind farms but they're not.  If man caused climate change is such a threat why isn't the IPCC recommending nuclear power plants? If wind and solar are so cheap and reliable why is Germany building a pipeline from Russia to Germany?  The good news is, CO2 a trace element in the atmosphere, is not the main driver of the planets climate. What most people do not understand is CO2 is just 4/10's of one percent of the atmosphere.  Water vapor, a greenhouse gas, has had far more impact, just look at millions of years of climate history.

text:
What about the other kind of denier? The denier who believes in climate change but still drives a car, because they cannot afford an EV?  Do you want to strangle them?

What about the person who like their home at 21°C in winter?  Are they a denier for not lowering their thermostat to 15°C and wearing winter clothes to bed?  What about someone who can afford an electric car but sell their old fossil fuel car rather than demolishing it?  Are they a denier?

Who exactly are you calling a denier?  Someone who denies there is a problem. Or someone who continues to use as much energy as necessary for comfort?

What about someone who buys an EV without realizing their electricity is coal based?

Who is a climate change denier?  I would say anyone who eats or breathes.

Agriculture generates 8% of all anthropogenic greenhouse gases,  Breathing another 7%.  This is not including the greenhouse gasses used in transportation and distribution of food.
