text:
"how can one individual not believe in climate change in 2018?" Simple. Look at the facts.
1) Artic ice started melting at least by 1800, likely before that.
2)Glaciers around the world show that they started melting in 1600's.
3) Sea level rise is based on the amount of rise cause by glaciers, not heat.4) Places alarmist use to prove sea level rise are all subsiding.
5) No model has been able to predict changes 5 years in the future, let alone 100. The closest is the Russian model (cant think of his name) who set his atmospheric sensitivity to .5° Those that predict disaster require it be at least 3° In 20 years they are off by a full degree already.

I could go on and on, but the facts do not support agw.
author: robert hicks

text: So you do believe climate change is real, you just don't think it's caused by humans but that's besides the point. If many independent scientists have concluded that the greenhouse effect is in fact real, then why wouldn't we at least try to do something about it? I mean, the faith of our planet is at stake here! Even if it doesn't work, at least we would've tried. Now we're set towards certain doom. And it's not like scientists aren't trustworthy, they were right in 1970 about the hole in the ozone layer and the situation has already improved.
author: Maxime K-G

text:
"If many independent scientists have concluded that the greenhouse effect is in fact real," Yes, greenhouse effect is real, but it isn't the entire story. You have negative feedbacks on top of positive, so the question is what it the atmospheric sensitivity. HISTORY has proven that the sensitivity is low.

"the faith … is at stake here" This is what the problem is. AGW is a religion based on fear of the future.

"Now we're set towards certain doom" What evidence is there of this? Models that require a sensitivity of at least 3°C where as history says it is .5°C or less.

"the situation has already improved" Has it? it got smaller for a while then got bigger again. CFC's are almost gone from the atmosphere, yet the hole is almost the same size. It decreased at one point to 10%, then increased to only 5% less than it was at its max.

" it's not like scientists aren't trustworthy" The problem is, you have a tiny group of people claiming everyone believes the same thing they do, when the evidence says that they do not. 54% of climatologist says there is no danger to co2 and only 22% says we have to do everything no matter what the cost to stop co2. The funny thing is, the same number said the same thing in another study, but that study discounted the other 78% to only 3%.

So, its not the large group that they tell you it is, but a tiny group that all have money, reputation, or power at stake if it is proven wrong. The 54% have nothing at stake. For the most part, the 24% that answered different than those two also have nothing to gain from not supporting or supporting agw.
author: robert hicks

text: @robert hicks  I understand what your saying. Just look at the facts. The problem is you need to look at all the facts not just the cherry picked ones that when pulled out of context can be used to validate what ever you believe to be right, but just because you believe something and can find some evidence to support and validate those beliefs doesn't mean you are right. In fact these days with the support of the internet you can find data to support any outlandish belief. Of course it doesn't really matter to people what the real truth is because they feel superior in there personal beliefs over the beliefs of others. The real facts have long proven that human activities have drastically changed the environment. Oh and what causes weather patterns? The environment! Human activities have in the past present and most definitely the future caused massive ecological disasters effecting entire ecosystems causing massive loss of life to plants animals and even humans. If you truly believe that humans have little to no effect on the planet and its systems then your scope of cognitive thought must be very close to the nano scale. You are however correct that the glaciers started melting long before the industrial revolution though. In fact that warming was part of the natural warming cycle of the planet. This is the warming that brought us out of the last ice age and made possible the Agricultural revolution which is thought to be the event that spawned modern humans & civilization. And very slowly over thousands of years the raise in temp continued. The difference between then and now is vast! The Industrial Revolution brought us into the tech age and mankind boomed like never before. Our population has risen so high that we have indeed invaded every facet on the surface of this planet. Individuals and small projects hardly seem like they could have an effect on this planet like this but when you scale those activities across the whole of the planet and the whole of mankind those numbers tell us something entirely different. The speed at which our planet is changing is indeed unprecedented in the entire known history of the planet. Yes climate naturally change over time but natural change occurs over hundreds of thousands of years. They dont happen over a few hundred years or even in several decades unless some outside direct traumatic force sets off runaway climate disasters. For example the first Ice age was caused by the over population of photosynthetic plant organisms pulling so much C02 from the air and adding so much O2 that it spiraled and caused a deep freeze. This still took hundreds of thousands of years to occur. Massive volcanic activity can set off both massive warming and mini Ice ages in various regions around the world throwing climates around the world out of wack. Big meteorite killed off dinosaurs and did pretty much the same. Caused extreme weather across the world and set in motion the Ice age that we came though as a species. My point is that the Human entity is large enough and effective enough to make real lasting effects on our world and climate. WW2 ended and the famous warning from Einstein and the other physicists who worked on the Manhattan  project stated that for the first time in history human beings have the technological capacity to effectively end life as we know it on planet earth. It was the study of math, physics, chemistry, biology, Astrology and ecology that enabled people to develop all the tech you see and use today. If you doubt the intelligent findings of the people who made the modern world possible through testable experimentation & observation on a matter that scientists and scholars across the board over vastly different studies have found massive amounts of data that all point to rapid climate change and mass extinction and all because humans have tampered with the natural ecosystems across the planet. Sorry to pontificate so radically but when things go well pass the point of no return. "we may already be too late!" It will be people like you who stand in the way of our life boat that will be beaten by the mobs torched & dismembered limb from limb. If you wanna stick your head in the sand and ignore the reality around you fine by all means. Just don't stand in the way of the rationally intelligent who actually understand to a reasonable degree what is happening and what needs to be done. Don't let this beautiful blue marble teaming with life go the rout of every other astral body in our solar system just because its too big for you to wrap your mind around therefore must be some crazy hoax conspiracy. This is the classic frog set to slow boil situation. The frog only knows somethings wrong long after its too late to jump. Global climate change happens so slowly in regards to our time perspective and is driven and effected by so many different variables that the scale of it is understandably difficult to understand and therefore believe. author: The Savage Method

text:
"The problem is you need to look at all the facts not just the cherry picked ones that when pulled out of context" That is seriously hilarious coming from an alarmist. That's the ONLY way they can create their alarms.

Take for instance the insistence on ONLY using the data from the END of the little ice age, as if the LIA was the NORMAL temperature instead of the EXTREMELY COLD it was. OR when they talk about the ice cap disappearing they ONLY count the years since the 1970's the bottom of the 60 year cycle.

"just because you believe something and can find some evidence to support and validate those beliefs doesn't mean you are right." Maybe, but what it means is that your THEORY has holes in it. AGW is a theory and if a theory has holes in it, according to standard scientific procedures, you remove it and either remaking where it takes into account all the data or you discard it. AGW zealots refuse to do either. They insist that it be given the status of scientific law.

"they feel superior in there personal beliefs over the beliefs of others." Did you bother to read what you wrote? It has nothing to do with belief. Belief is religion. Science is data. IF the data does not match your theory, you adjust your theory. Agw zealots ADJUST THE DATA to match what they BELIEVE.

The truth does not care what you believe or do not believe. The fact is, the warming started long before co2 went up. The fact is, temperature increases do not track co2 increases. The fact is, the co2 based model are all wrong. The fact is the north pole ice cap was at its greatest at the end of the little ice age, not 1970. It has melted every since. None of that cares if you believe or not. They are scientific facts. They are PROVEN facts.

"The real facts have long proven that human activities have drastically changed the environment." Yes we have. With farming, with damming or channeling of rivers, with building cities, with mining, with pumping water out of the earth to irrigate deserts and more. BUT NOT with co2. We have polluted rivers and the skies. We have used pesticides that kill off insects and birds. We have destroyed animal habitats. We have fished some fish and hunted some animals to the edge of extinction, and possibly over the edge with a few.

But we can not tax any of those and that's what this is about.

They want to take away our rights. They want to take away our money. They want to take away our homes. They want us to be dependent on the government so they can order us to do what ever they choose. And that's why there will be a war. The time is coming when YOU will have to decide if your religion is more important that rights.
author: robert hicks

text:
"The speed at which our planet is changing is indeed unprecedented in the entire known history of the planet" No, it isn't. The earth warmed up 1° in 25 years in the late 1600's. It has only warmed up 1.1° in the last 120 years. There were periods where it has warmed over 2°C in a single century. There is nothing unprecedented in what has happened in the last century. There was a time sea levels rose by feet per year, where we have only had 3 MILLIMETERS in 5 years. The last 20 years rose the same amount as the first 20 years of the 1900's.

"natural change occurs over hundreds of thousands of years. " No, they don't. There was a period 12000 years ago when the temperature dropped 5°C in a single 250 period. After a short time, it rose again. After the mwp, the temperature dropped 3°C in a matter of a century or so. Changes can happen rapidly.

The only place you will find that the earth does not change rapidly is the much disproven hockey stick graph.

" This is the warming that brought us out of the last ice age" No, that is the beginning of the Holocene maximum period. I was talking about the little ice age of a few centuries ago, not 12000 years ago. During the little ice age, the ice expanded a lot. After the little ice age, the glaciers began to retreat, but that was in spirts. The first was after 1650, and the last one was 150 years ago. THAT is when the glaciers began to retreat in the artic and in Canada and places like that.

Look at this graph. http://www.co2science.org/subject/other/figures/temp10000.jpg

As you can see it rose rapidly in the first few thousand years, then for a long time it was much hotter than it is now. Then the little ice age hit and it fell a lot. It has not recover that since.

In proper scientific procedures you do not change the method of measurement in the middle of a graph. The only way they can FAKE the hockey stick, is to stop using proxies at around 1950.

"For example the first Ice age was caused by the over population of photosynthetic plant organisms pulling so much C02 from the air and adding so much O2 that it spiraled and caused a deep freeze." No, it didn't. What cause the ice age we are currently in was the impact of the Indian and Eurasian plates creating the Himalayan mountains and the Antarctic plate drifting over the south pole and freezing. Co2 was 1000 ppm at that time. Co2 has been falling for millions of years but for the most part temperature were stable. Then the plates collided and the temperature fell. Then Antarctica drifted of the pole and it froze.
author: robert hicks

text:
"Big meteorite killed off dinosaurs and did pretty much the same. Caused extreme weather across the world and set in motion the Ice age that we came though as a species." So your saying the dinosaurs and humans existed at the same time? No, we did not come through the asteroid strike that killed the dinosaurs "as a species". Yes our ancestors did, but they were tiny little things, little bigger than rodents, that didn't need the food supply the bigger animals needed. 

The "nuclear winter" that would have happened would have lasted no more than a couple decades and since it was so hot, its effect would not be that long lasting. Because it was so  hot before the asteroid impacted, the planet did NOT go into an ice age.

"If you wanna stick your head in the sand and ignore the reality around you fine by all means." I am not the one that is ignoring reality. I read the REAL scientific journals, ones that you can only post articles about the scientific disciple IF you are a trained and working member of that disciple and it is reviewed by members ONLY of that disciple. Because those scientific fields are so well establish there are plenty of people in that field they can call on to have people review your article.

As comparison, look at an article written by a marine biologist, published in nature, who claimed that since it was about the climate's effect on reefs, and since there aren't many people that study that, he needed certain people to review it. They allowed him to choose his reviewers, and he reviewed their papers so of course he was going to be 'nice' to them and allow their paper.

No one questioned why he used CORRELATION to determine the death of the reefs. NO one asked for proof that it was the ph that was killing the reefs. NO one question if they had recovered.

IF he had posted in a marine biology/oceanography peer review, it would have been shredded because there were plenty of LABORATORY evidence of it being due to pollution from ships being too close and from people walking on the reefs. There were also many articles that showed that when they restricted the ships to a certain distance and people banned from walking on the reefs, they recovered.

You are not being lead to life boats, you are being led to the slave pens.

In other words ozone and oxygen radicals are turning into oxygen molecules. It is proven that CFCs break down ozone.

text:
To be honest, you are the first person to respond to that with anything other than "but nutrition levels stay the same". Kudos. I always find that one funny, since the vast majority of plant life is not on our dinner plate.

Also, just an FYI. The IPCC stated they dramatized the report because they did not get a strong enough response last time around. They are doing what all the media is doing now, which is using fear to sway public opinion and drive viewership. 

PS. I believe we should focus of pollutants prior to focusing on CO2. The Earth has a robust CO2 cycle, which can and always does modify itself to achieve balance. CO2 is not a pollutant, in fact it is a driver of the life cycle. Furthermore, fossil fuels are already out of date. As such, based on our current rate of advancement, they will be replaced with something cheaper, more convenient, and abundant or renewable in the near future regardless of fossil fuels' effects on the climate. For these reasons, and many more, I believe our efforts would be better placed reducing toxic chemical exposures, better recycling technology, something to replace plastic for disposables and packaging, reducing particulate emissions into the air, potable water infrastructure, sanitation, etc, etc, etc. CO2 should not be anywhere near the top of the list.
author: Rowebot Radio

text:
Rowebot Radio Just because CO2 is not normally a pollutant doesn’t mean introducing so much of it to the atmosphere isn’t damaging. Water is necessary for us to survive, but drinking enough of it is lethal. Too much of a good thing is a bad thing. 

And again, the CO2 issue is one of many problems. Combined with rampant deforestation, human-led mass extinction, ocean acidification, and disappearing ice poles, it contributes to a massive problem that needs immediate and drastic attention. If the IPCC are exaggerating, which you haven’t proven they are, it’s to a necessary end. The fact is that we need to address this problem before the planet is uninhabitable, which will impact low-income and developing communities before major world players. Wealthy countries will likely wait until issues effect them before acting, at which point the Earth’s most vulnerable populations will be decimated. If the IPCC is actively trying to prevent that and save lives, then they have a goddamned point.

text: China is still using coal and oil and  haven't slowed down , as are the  newly emerging countries. Wood burning is  just as bad.  Humans  will do  what they are  going to do. We  need to start   doing carbon capture and conversion to slow this process down as well as  going green , not  driving everywhere, eco friendly home design ,and reducing the number of children we  bring into the world  to   add to the  weight of CO2 emissions. People are  naturally greedy and they aren't going to scale back readily. This is unfortunate  for the  life on this  planet.  We also  have to  deal with the permafrost problem of  Co2 and methane release which  has started kicking in as   our world  has heated up due to  our Co2 production. That process  has  already been started and will be hard to stop   even if everyone on the  planet got on  board to   get to  zero emissions of Co2.  Since 90%  of people  live on the coastlines of the planet , the sea levels will be the first and nastiest concern of climate change. People who  don't die in the floods   of  strong storms and general sea level rise will move inland to   put more  pressure on those inland. The sheer numbers of the  fleeing will probably overwhelm the infrastructures and  smaller populations in the interiors of  nations .

text: This video gives me such a feeling of hopelessness for the future. Once upon a time, the biggest dividing factor on climate change was money. Companies that create CO2 emissions and other greenhouse gases as part of their manufacturing processes would pump tons of money into electoral campaigns to ensure that climate change deniers would find themselves in the seats of power. Now? Now it's not just about money. It's about "us vs them". Democrats vs Republicans. It's no longer a financial or scientific debate, but an ideological one. If there is one thing that history has shown it is that opposing ideological views rarely ever come to agreement, and even when they do it is after many, many years of struggle. Years that we don't have to waste.

Believing we live in a world where nothing can go wrong is ignorant. They talked about temperature change "when the dinosaurs where around". The dinosaurs roamed the earth for approximately 170 MILLION YEARS and went extinct 65 million years ago(in comparison, humans became smart about 50k years ago).  If temperature changed a degree (Celsius) or two in such a big time period, the ecosystem would have adjusted. Right now where talking about development that has started only 200 years ago and has exploded in the last 50 years. text: All the climate change that is occurring now and will occur in the future is totally predictable.  We know what the Milankovitch cycles are and we know that 120,000 years ago, at the peak of the last warming cycle, the earth was warmer than it is today and we know that the sea level was about 25' higher than it is today.  We should realize that as the earth warms, which started about 16,000 years ago, after the last ice age, the ice sheet melts and as the ice melts, the sea level rises.  These cycles will continue and there is nothing man has done to cause it and there is nothing man can do to prevent it. Instead of wasting all this time, effort and money on something that man hasn’t caused and can’t stop, we should be preparing for the inevitable.

text: The answer is to reforest the planet!  You're not going to stop the oil cartel(s) from squeezing the planet for all its fossil fuels... there's simply too much money to be made... and we also need oil for making plastics, rubber, asphalt, paints/dyes, clothes/nylon, carpets, contact lenses, pharmaceuticals, caulking, etc.  Riding a bike instead of a car is insignificant compared to industrial uses... and is ultimately insufficient to stop climate change. Trees take CO2 out of the air, locking it away... cutting them down removes the CO2 from the system and gives us useful material (of course we plant new trees as we remove the mature ones.. and avoid clear-cutting the entire area... responsible forestry for the win!). Concrete production generates a lot of CO2, as does vinyl siding... we should be using more wood and planting more trees.

author: W

text:
Once again Vox, what a skewed view on the truth of the situation. This entire 12 min video is dedicated to portray the Republicans as bad and the Democrats as good.

I have two problems with this video. First of all, it assumes change can be visible in the course of twelve years. This is false, especially when it comes to a problem that has been going on for 200 years. Besides, the awareness of climate change has improved and we can expect this to show results in the following 3 decades.

The biggest problem however with this video, is how you make use of those two graphs to enforce your biased opinion without any context.
The thing is, the temperature rise and polar ice decrease hardly has anything to do with US politics. The truth is that countries such as China and India, both the most populated countries in the world, have been developing intensely for the past 12 years. This leads to more consumption of energy and thus more carbon emissions.
Leaving this fact out to share your badly argumented opinion is sickening.

Listen, I know climate change is real and I find it a serious issue, and yes, our politics have to adapt to this problem. Nevertheless, we shouldn't expect change overnight nor within one generation and we especially shouldn't alter the truth of the situation to manipulate people into a way of thinking.

Disappointed in you Vox, as always.

text: Everything depends on how quickly we end the burning fossil fuels. Realistic projections have the global temperature increase at around 3.2°C by year 2100. There is only a 5% chance that warming will be less than 2°C. Increases in CO2 concentration in the atmosphere are largely irreversible for 1,000 years after emissions stop. Even if carbon emissions stop completely today, as the oceans heating catches up to greenhouse gases already in the atmosphere, the Earth's temperature will rise another ~0.6°C. Scientists refer to this as committed warming.

text:
Rick Perry's argument at 5:00 made no sense, Galileo used the scientific method to support heliocentrism while the Catholic Church denied it without reason. In this case, the scientific method evidently shows global warming occurring and once again, it is those that do not believe in the scientific method, like Perry who stand in the way.

While this example really means "listen to the scientific method", Perry illogically uses it to claim that "We can't trust the majority", supporting the idea that the minority is correct. Facts aren't established by democracy, neither the majority nor the minority is ever inherently correct. It is the studying of objective fact through the scientific method that is correct, and those who have studied this agree that global warming is a major issue.

Perry's comment is indicative of the hypocrisy that has become associated with the Republican party.

@Miguel I think you're confused; you're most likely referring to the Law of Conservation of Energy. Energy is not created nor destroyed according to this law, not matter.

Also, just to add insult to injury, the Law of Conservation of Energy is technically not true in some situations, like when a positron and electron collide to make photon energy.

author: Gr4vity Goat

text:
"first of all, you can't make or destroy matter."

Yes, you can. A positron and an electron (i.e. matter) colliding and dissipating into photon energy (i.e. light) is an example of matter being destroyed and energy being created. What did you think E = mc^2 was referring to?
author: Baryonyx89

text: Also, looking back at my post, I take back what I said about Miguel's confusion over the laws of conservation. However, my point still stands that he is wrong about "nothing is created nor destroyed" AND that he is wrong about "CO2 is already present in some form". CO2 is CO2; it's not conserved by being in a different "form". It can be created, and it can be consumed.

text: Miguel Hernandez Yup, it was present as organic (carbon) substances in this earth. It’s how the carbon cycle works— these organic substances contain high energy covalent bonds that produce energy that basically powers our society. Yes, the carbon was there before, but it wasn’t as CO2. What we need to do is to fix that CO2 back into organic carbon substances (which is done in photosynthesis), and at least slow down what we’re doing now. The problem is we’re not doing either.

author: Alexander Gonzalez

text:
@carl1223:

The problem isn't solved by simply naming the obstacles in the way of solving it.  One takes that first step of acknowledging these obstacles, but figures that there can be some means to compromise between conservation, efficiency, and alternatives in order to make progress and eventually meet the end goal.  The next step is figuring out what could work and going for it.  Will there be some R&D and breakthroughs needed?  Yes.  Will some sacrifices possibly have to be made?  Sure.  The point is, we don't know what is impossible until we try, and our 30-some years of procrastination and tepid attempts to try haven't produced all that much progress.  The goal, some measure of human population living on this planet without excessively altering its condition in a way that threatens that human population.  Ideas how that can happen, or you aren't contributing anything helpful.

text: The US has also been the major producer for world for the last half century.  And like many developed countries has production facilities that are a century or older.  India and China have entered the mass production recently and have the benefit of all of the advanced technology (pollution reduction) at a cheaper price and not having to retro fit their manufacturing (and the knowledge of the toxicity of materials not previously known).  Yet China and India do not invest the minor price increase of better pollution reduction (at building of their facilities) and have vastly increased their pollution production.  In many ways they have gone the opposite way and not implemented even the minimum of controls.  While the US has spent vast amounts of money to increase pollution control and reduce its pollution emission while China and India have vastly increased their pollution creation .  There are vast differences in the emissions requirement in the US (stringent) and China and India (almost zero).  It is the height of hypocrisy to demand some follow stringent regulations while ignoring others.  But that is not a surprise when two of the most prominent "climate change leader/cheerleader" Al Gore and Leonardo DiCaprio demand everyone else reduce their emissions while both are the single largest producers of the pollution they decry (both Gore and DiCaprio use more resources than small towns of regular people).  While the US innovates to reduce its emissions and is still castigated for improving itself the same people who castigate the US turn an absolute blind eye to the lack of any environmental control by China and India.
author: BeukendaalMason

text: Even people in China and India understand and believe in man's role in climate change. It's only in America that people actually decide to believe or refute the facts based on the color of their state.

The problem is that due to human activity they are melting thousands of times faster than that, and if we continue they will melt in a few hundred years. author: Misadventure

text:
@warlord13000

The problem with the thinking that we as individuals can figure out how to do this on our own, is that no tragedy of the commons type problem has ever been solved that way.  There are some reasons borrowed from game theory, but individuals don't naturally just band together to fix a public common problem like this.  There is no organization and everybody ends up just doing a negligible amount or the bare minimum (often nothing) due to refusals to make larger sacrifices than any given neighbor or other citizen.  It ends up as a race to the bottom, doing nothing or next to nothing as we have seen on AGW the past 30 some years.  It is wishful thinking that we all just suddenly become aware and change this do-nothing trend massively.  Like it or loathe it, but other problems like this had to be solved by some form of enforcement, whether it was the saving of the last bits of the Great Plains buffalo herds or the Montreal Protocol to get a handle on the ozone layer problem.  We didn't win WWII by just figuring everybody would make a weapon or two and send them over to our boys to retake conquered lands from the Axis.  Why would this problem that requires substantial economic mobilization be any different?
author: Ryan Otte

text: No, it isn't a matter of waiting until someone else fixes the problem.  On the contrary, there is quite a lot of room for engaged citizens to make efforts to lobby for policy or organized solutions.  Also, tragedy of the commons problems don't exclude individual actions.  There is no reason why many individuals can't make certain lifestyle changes along with the system-level changes.  Both can be done.  It is just that lifestyle changes on an individual level don't work on their own, or at least haven't worked on their own for these types of problems in the past.  So it is a matter of focus... focusing one's individual efforts towards pushing for systematic change.
author: Ryan Otte

text:
What are you even talking about? Do you mean the coal workers losing their jobs, unable to afford the education for retraining wanting the government to intervene; or the young adults complaining about the cost of college, expecting politicians to change that for them?

Because if you're talking about individual citizens making the efforts to combat climate change themselves, then I would tell you the infrastructure for that is greatly lacking or non-exsistent in many places. Recycling isn't always convenient or possible, and as said, many cities with these centers are unable to accomodate most of the plastic which ends up in landfills because they can't accept it. Our economy is such that our nation is bankrupt many times over, indebted to other nations and most families struggle to provide necessities for themselves and their families, nevermind the idea of a brand new fuel-efficient vehicle (or any transportation besides the public transit) is alien to them.

The government is just as accountable as average citizens, if not more so, because the government has greater power to influence that change, holding corporate and industrial polluters accountable where the people are powerless, and to inspire and rally others to help it make that change possible.

text:
@Kevin Lai  The risk of nuclear waste contamination is not, under any realistic scenario, comparable to the risk from climate change. Firstly, as crude as it sounds, digging a very deep hole and burying the waste is actually a pretty effective safety measure - sites are carefully selected based on their geology so that, even if humans were to disappear tomorrow, no additional radiation would be felt at the surface - in some places they even design them with the return of ice sheets in thousands of years in mind. Secondly, nuclear waste and climate change are on completely incomparable scales as hazards - nuclear accidents/waste residues are localised, the effects are predictable and quantifiable, and dimish to levels that aren't that harmful, to humans or especially the environment, pretty quickly. At worst, people can just move away from the affected area. Climate change screws over humanity and the environment in so many ways, it's hard to know where to start. 

Nuclear power stations aren't the only way of generating electricity, but until we can find a way of storing electricity or efficiently transmitting it long distances, intermittent renewables present issues if you want to move to 100% fossil-fuel free electricity. As it stands, when the sun isn't shining and the wind doesn't blow, you need fossil fuel or nuclear plants to keep the lights on - this isn't a problem when renewables make up a minority of the energy mix, but we need to do better than that.

author: Kevin Lai

text:
@Merry Machiavelli  ok so i just reread my comment and I saw how it could be misunderstood as "i think nuclear contamination is a greater threat than climate change". consider this thought experiment. Suppose you decommision every nuclear powerplant in the U.S. and replaced with fossil fuels. Yes, it will accelerate climate change. But by how much? More to the point, how much earlier will we reach tipping point threshold and what would be the difference in human fatalities?  Now lets consider the reverse scenario. Lets say some catastrophic incident results in all the nuclear waste in all nuclear plants to be leaked into the environment. how many lives will be lost directly or indirectly? is this number greater or less than the former scenario? 
I have no idea. but if the latter is higher, then i must conclude the threat of nuclear contamination is greater than the threat of a accelerated global warming due to replacing nuclear plants with fossil fuel plants.
author: Kevin Lai

text:
@Kevin Lai  In answer to the first part of that question, the amount of CO2 (or CO2 equivalent) emissions of different energy sources is generally measured in CO2 per kilowatt hour, with most estimates taking full life cycle costs into account. I can't be bothered to track down a thoroughly reliable source for those stats (although I have in the past). but to give an indication of relative scale is the median estimates produced by a 2014 IPCC report;

Coal - 820
Gas - 490
Solar PV (utility) - 48
Solar PV (rooftop) - 41
Offshore wind - 12
Nuclear - 12

Now, I can't defend those precise figures (the emissions involved in Solar energy relative to other forms, in particular, is probably complicated and down to the manufacturing process), but they do chime with what I've seen in other sources. According to official US EIA, nuclear makes up 20% of electricity generation in the US. I'm not going to sit down and do the maths, and how bad the effect would be depends on whether you are switching to coal or natural gas, but the increase in emissions clearly wouldn't be trivial. Would it single-handedly be responsible for global climate change? No, but it might be enough that we see, say, a fraction of a degree more warming by the end of the century than if that had not happened. That means a little bit more sea level rise, a little bit worse drought in the Sahel, a little bit worse flooding in South Asia, a little increase in global food prices (leading to a little increase in the risk of civil unrest in some countries)...etc.. Putting a firm number of lives on that is impossible, or at least, not something I'm willing to do, but on a global scale over a long period of time, I'd expect numbers in at least the six or seven figures.

Now you say 'catastrophic incident'...what catastrophic incident? Calculating risk is about measuring the severity of a hazard against its likelihood. A hazard which is very severe, but is very unlikely does not constitute a risk - hence why governments aren't constantly in a panic over asteroids or nearby supernova. If nulcear waste is buried deep underground, in spots far apart geographically, nothing short of a planetary collision would cause all of it to leak. And at that point, radiation would be the least of our problems. It's not in anyway comparable to climate change - we know would happen, if emissions increase, and it is obviously realistic that they could. 

Seriously though, if you can name me one hazard, other than human tampering, that could cause stored nuclear waste all over the US to leak at once without also wiping out human civilisation, I would be eager to hear it.
author: Merry Machiavelli

text:
Wallowing in despair helps nothing; the tone of this video is just discouraging, and at a time when further discouragement is not necessary. 

And it's only part of the story. Yes, in the United States many politicians have dragged their heels every inch of the way, but the past 20 years has still seen dramatic improvements in terms of emissions per kilowatt hour, and a huge improvement in fuel economy for our vehicles. We have been doing better, and while we have distance to go, there is hope. 

The potential for proven technology; wind, solar, smarter grid systems, electric vehicles; has only begun to be tapped. This isn't hypothetical anymore, this is stuff that is competing on the market and winning. 

Coal is already a dying industry, and in 10 or 15 years, oil is likely to follow. 

So if you care about climate change, turn this video off, and go find out what you can do in your own life to make a change. Get out there and vote, support organizations that promote environmentally sustainable technology, volunteer your time. Whatever you can do. Together we will continue the transition to a sustainable economy.

text: There are two ways to be suspicious about the current climate pun intended about climate change: if you believe that the earth is getting warmer, as it seems to be the case, that doesn't mean the world 'is coming to and end'. We, as human beings, should adapt just as we shouldn't build houses near the coast so the next hurricane just don't blow the whole thing up. It's always weird when we talk about 'natural disasters' we don't ask ourselves how 'natural' they are. And that was only an example because we know that there's no scientific evidence, according to the IPCC, for a correlation between climate change and hurricanes and storms. In the last century temp went up 1°C and that wasn't the most important event of the century, think about the catastrophic events of WWI and WWII. So even if things change in the future that doesn't mean is going to be worse. The other way to see it is that the whole scientific premise is wrong: is way too difficult to even measure the planet temp. There's a scientific and a social and moral problem to the 'consensus'. And finally what is it that I should be convinced? Climate change is real, probably getting warmer, not so sure but let's say man-made is part of it, but the lack of encouragement to adapt, instead of trying to keep things as they are which is very costly, and the moral argument make it difficult to digest.

text: It is hard to pick one defining moment, but you can look up a memo by Frank Luntz from a strategy meeting with Republican party officials.  In it, there is an infamous line about how to use certain words that don't sound as scary to the public "use climate change instead of global warming" and the whole summary is couched in the political party's goals and not much concerned about whether the scientific problem is significant.  Other than that, there have been certain fossil fuel industry public relation efforts that have been evolving since the late 1980's that have tried to make some political statements about the science.
author: Ryan Otte

text: On this particular issue, that isn't the case.  This isn't opposition for the sake of opposition.  One party is acknowledging and coming up with suggested solutions to a problem that has been clearly identified by the National Academy of Sciences (in the USA and basically every single equivalent science organization in countries across the world.).  The other party is simply denying this scientific recommendation to do something, claiming the problem is unsolvable, for economic/monetary reasons.  By and large, special interest donors are determining this one-sided denial effect.

text:
I do agree with the video that this is a government issue but there is also so much that WE can do as citizens of this country to make the changes necessary. We know we cannot count and rely on our government so we need to find ways to take matters into our own hands and work together. Yes, one thing we can do is go out and vote that does help. But what a lot of people also don’t realize is that one of the easiest ways to help combat climate change is our consumption and I’m not just talking about oil and fossil fuels I’m also talking about the actual food we eat. 

It is known that the animal agriculture industry is one of of the top contributors to greenhouse gases in our atmosphere so we, as a collective can make a conscious effort to consume less. The less consumption, the less demand there will be and therefore less supply will be needed. 

I’m not saying you need to be 100% vegan or vegetarian but at least taking one or two days out of your week to not consume animal products can make a huge difference! I know people hate vegans and they always think they’re all righteous and what not but please do your own research and see how much of a difference we can all make if we just made minor lifestyle adjustments. 

Same thing goes for waste, be conscious of your plastic use and try to use reusable items when possible. 

Don’t wait for these clowns in Washington to save us. They won’t, most of them are going to die soon anyway and just care about how much money they have in the bank. 

WE HAVE MORE POWER THAN THEM. 

They rely on our fear and ignorance to push their ridiculous agendas, don’t give them that power. It’s time to take it back!

text: I agree with the content of this video, Vox, but I don't like the music track behind it.  It distracts from the main content, which is people talking - at various levels of audibility.  Adding music for me to filter out makes it needlessly difficult to hear the actual content.  Second, the music was chosen to 'set the mood' - which is unnecessary in this situation.  It smacks of programming the viewer or pandering, and is in my opinion a cheap trick.  Let the message - via everyone's quotes - speak for itself.  This probably seems like a minor issue I'm quibbling about to most people, but I think it's symbolic of a general trend (especially in Youtube) videos of over-production at the detriment of conveying meaning.   For such a professional outfit like Vox to do this surprises me.

text:
No. Carbon dioxide lags temperature; it does not cause it to increase and warm the planet. In other words, the hotter Earth becomes, the more CO2 is released from various natural sources. [It's well known that in a warm El Nino year, more CO2 is released by the ocean into the atmosphere (and less taken up by the ocean from the atmosphere), while during cool La Nina years just the opposite happens.] Read that again, the hotter Earth becomes, the more CO2 is released from various natural sources. In other words, the entire premise of anthropogenic or "man made" global warming (AGW) where increased atmospheric CO2 causes the temperature to rise is flawed from the beginning.

To reiterate, global temperatures have been rising for the last 300 years since the Little Ice Age (LIA) and even climate alarmists cannot blame human activity as the cause. Now the scary part; there has been no increase in the earth's average temperature for over 18 years despite the increase in CO2 in the atmosphere. This recovery from the LIA is completely beneficial. Earlier springs and later falls means longer growing seasons and longer growing seasons means more food. Then there is that well-recognized 800-year global heating and cooling cycle and the undeniable effects of solar fluctuations and cosmic activity that just may have some small effect on our world's temperature. Need I remind you cold winters kill more people than hot summers?

You're asking for more taxes, more laws, less freedoms and creating a market where only the largest conglomerates will survive. It is everything I am against. You unknowingly do this as you have been indoctrinated at school and at home via the television; both of which are controlled by the same people. (Leonardo Dicaprio fly's around on his jet to tell us all to ride bicycles and is a UN climate change ambassador. Another corrupt organization hell-bent on NWO.)

text:
Just in case anyone is wondering what specifically is causing climate change, I will try to explain it now.

Greenhouse gases trap heat from the sun in the Earth’s atmosphere, not allowing it to escape to space. Due to industrialisation, the amount of greenhouse gases released into the atmosphere has increased dramatically over the last 150 years. Carbon Dioxide, the most common greenhouse gas, is produced by burning fossil fuels. A fossil fuel is a natural fuel like coal or gas which is created from dead organisms buried under the ground for millions of years. These fuels are not created fast enough to keep up with our current demand and we will run out of them some day. Fossil fuels are used to generate electricity and power transportation such as cars, airplanes and boats. In 2007, fossil fuels made up 86.4% of the world’s energy consumption. Due to this, a large amount of carbon dioxide is released into the environment from the production of energy. Plants are naturally supposed to convert Carbon Dioxide back into oxygen. Unfortunately, due to deforestation there are less plants to do this. Climate change will cause sea levels to rise, causing massive flooding all over the world, cause the average temperature to increase and will inevitably make it harder for life to exist on Earth.

text:
@Mert Garbonite  Here is what is going on.  Yes the Earth has had many climatic cycles.  The Earth has been doing it for billions of years.  Hot and cold ones.  But here is the important part.  Our actions are accelerating what is a natural event.  In the past it took the planet a thousand plus years to increase the median temperature a degree.  Now we are doing it in the span of 150 or so years thru our actions.  The ecosystems that humanity grew up with and depend on since the last ice age depends on the temperature ranges the Earth existet with for the last 7 or so thousand years.  Most of our cities were created with the temperature ranges of the last millennia.

Our actions are creating a new world (for lack of another term).

text:
R Lewis structurally that makes sense but how many degrees temp rise until we have really screwed with the ecosystem ? Like I said I know we are causing harm but if we accelerate a 10 thousand year process by 50 times we still have 200 years of safety net, and that's from right now not the start of the industrial revolution or anything. I keep hearing oh population explosion and fossil fuels mean were doomed but it just doesnt make sense, Europe's population is steady and in some cases declining , who is to say Africa india and China won't do so aswell when they catch up to the level of development Europe is at now. Every year solar and fusion become more viable (wind is stuck behind a physics barrier) and as soon as its actually cheaper than coal and NG it will be immediately implemented so companies can make the most money. 

The precautionary principle better safe than sorry doesnt apply here either.  Renewables are just more expensive than fossile fuels and mandating their usage means that less people get power. Maybe our cities have to move inland but millions of African lives are cut short burning wood fires indoors because of lack of electricity, electricity we could easily make with coal plant technology and African natural resources. 
In summary where is the evidence that this is worse than bad and will be catastrophic before the next 100 years is up and are we sure enough of this to force China india and Africa to follow standards we ourselves did not when we were where they are now?

text:
There's a few big factors. The internet age has decentralized sources of information and put disinformation and propaganda on the same footing as evidence-based research and study. Oil and coal companies see their futures in jeopardy and they have been fueling anti-global warming propaganda for the past 40 years, with each year further entrenching those opinions among relevant demographics. President Obama's efforts to fight climate change were opposed by the GOP as part of a broader effort to undermine his presidency and protect their political power. And perhaps most of all, there is a growing sense of despair as we come to realize that measures to stop global climate change are increasingly harmful to our way of life. 30 years ago, it may have been possible to stop climate change with a cap and trade bill and investments in renewable energy. Now, however, extreme financial burdens would really be required at this point to ensure that we stop climate change.

Unfortunately, this isn't going to change without a true sea change within the GOP, and among the nation at large. Realistically, $10/gallon for gas, flights for $1k or more for cross-country flights, and exorbitant coal/natural gas electric power would be necessary, and right now, Americans (among others) aren't going to give up their comforts to save the planet.

text:
PREVENTING CLIMATE CHANGE
(Small things you can do to make a difference)

Take public transit.
Ride a bike.
Car-share.
Switch to an electric or hybrid vehicle.
Dont use straws
Fly less (if you do fly, make sure you offset your emissions).

Change to energy-efficient light bulbs.

Unplug computers, TVs and other electronics when you’re not using them.

Wash clothes in cold or warm (not hot) water.

Dryers are energy hogs, so hang dry when you can and use dryer balls when you can’t.

Install a programmable thermostat.

Look for the Energy Star label when buying new appliances.

Winterize your home to prevent heat from escaping.

Get a home or workplace energy audit to identify where you can make the most energy-saving gains.

Consume less, waste less, enjoy life more

author: MineCraft Ruined

text: MineCraft Ruined it makes the earth hotter because it the carbon dioxide allows the sun’s rays to heat up the atmosphere, but prevents that heat from escaping the atmosphere. As for your second argument, it’s pretty simple really. The carbon dioxide is causing the ozone layer to become thinner and in some places, disappear altogether. The ozone layer is what protects the earth from the sun’s radiation. Without the ozone layer, the sun’s rays can reach the earth’s surface with little to no interference, causing the earth’s temperature to rise at a higher rate. Also, the ozone layer is NOT what keeps heat or gasses inside of the atmosphere, dumbass. The carbon dioxide will stay in the atmosphere regardless. So, 1. The thinning of the ozone layer is causing the earth to heat at a higher rate, and 2. The carbon dioxide is preventing that heat from leaving the atmosphere. I know this comment is a tad bit late, but I sincerely hope that you or any other climate change deniers read it.

text:
Toward the end of the video, there was a bit regarding the views of other nations on the US withdrawal from the Paris agreement. While the news no doubt skewed the information in support of climate change reform, the Vatican's suggestion that the US now threatens the entire world with its denial of climate change raised a question in my mind:

If our nation is a threat to the rest of the world, then when can we as ordinary US citizens expect other nations to take emergency defensive measures against the USA? Because that's what's happening. By ignoring climate change, we are threatening other nations and their citizens, and they'll be forced to retaliate (hopefully before its too late, not that I want anybody to die obviously).

Climate change has indeed become a matter of national security. "Make America great again," indeed; it has become a great threat to the rest of the world.

text:
A bunch of liberals used to talk about how climate change was a republican attempt to take money from the poor. Then they suddenly changed their tact and started supporting carbon tax. Wonder what change their minds. Maybe the realization they could use it to give money to poor nations?

The original plan was to tax companies for their use of carbon and to give that money back to the public, in the form of things designed to give people incentives to reduce co2. The liberals came up with the idea of creating carbon credits that could be purchased form people that did things in their normal life, such as logging companies planting trees that they will later cut down. Since these credits are so much cheaper than the tax, no one pays taxes so no money goes to the public. Instead companies that put up windmills and sell the electricity gets credits that they can sell to other companies so they do not have to reduce co2. This gets passed on to consumers of those companies, so that the consumers are supporting the windmills. This allows the windmills companies to sell electricity cheaper, making it look like the system is cheaper.

The big winners are the people that have stock in the trading companies.

Alcohol Credit for Fuel Excise Tax ($11.6 billion)
Renewable Electricity Production Credit ($5.2 billion)
Corn-Based Ethanol ($5.0 billion)

"In 2016 the Congressional Budget Office estimates that energy-related tax preferences in the U.S. cost $18.4 billion in 2016. Nearly $11 billion went toward renewable energy, $2.7 billion for energy efficiency and electricity transmission, and $4.6 billion for fossil fuels, the budget office said. The estimates do not include every program that affects the energy supply, such as research programs, tax breaks that apply more broadly to industry like depletion allowances, or the value of leasing on federal lands for coal, gas and oil extraction". When these were taken into account the U.S. provides more than $20 billion in fossil fuel subsidies alone each year.

TL;DR, Blame GM

We rarely get sun and the times we do get sun, it's normally 18° other countries have it differently but we deal with hellish weather 24/7, no joke, we literally had a day where within the space of 30 mins, we had snow, rain, hail, thunder, dicey weather and sun. So all those who doubt climate change, please educate yourself I am fed up with the extremely hot weather and our houses are not designed for the heat, there is a reason why most houses are on the ground with few windows, I don't care what any government says, climate change does exist and if we don't do something now, we are basically writing a suicide note, yes, we won't see results immediately but in the long run, we will have saved the planet from potential doom

text:
Well humanity... we had a good run... it wasn't all bad. Yeah we f***ed up a lot, be we also exhibited many great wonders and achievements. I suppose if that is our complex legacy, chaotic, yet orderly, neutral, a mixed bag, then I'm content with that. I take solace in the fact there will be a world after us.
The earth will recover, as it always does and has. We will be but a brilliant yet short speck in its history. A blip in the grand scheme. Eventually, the earth will recover as if nothing happened. New species will evolve and diversify to fill the niches we opened in our mass extinction. A new era of life can begin. The continents the climate, the earth, the biota of this world, will march forward and carry on with out us. Evolution by natural selection, will create new, and bizarre forms of life. We will drive ourselves extinct before we even begin to do real damage to the planet. Our impact, however large to us, is ultimately pathetic and weak compared to other events. One of my only regrets would be I can't see millions of years in the future, to see what our Earth has done without us.
If time is so short, then we ought to live for the most now. Help other people, try to advance humanity, enjoy ourselves, while we still can. In the end it will all mean nothing, so we get to dictate what it does mean for us.

+Purple Churros +Zoe Phin... No... there are no reasons to deny climate change.
Source: https://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/
Source: https://www.edf.org/climate/9-ways-we-know-humans-triggered-climate-change

That second source has links to scientific studies to back up all of its claims... That first source is NASA. And no... scientists are not being bribed into saying it is real... it just is real. Do you know how many scientists you would have to bribe? Hundreds of Millions! Because it is scientists all over the world saying that climate change is happening! And the reason there is a carbon tax is to encourage companies to switch to green energy! 

And CO2 emissions are changing the environment... this has already been proven by basic physics and chemistry... and I mean basic. 

+Zoe Phin
Who taught you that CO2 does not absorb heat? Because that is wrong and has been proven wrong multiple times. 
Source: https://skepticalscience.com/history-climate-science.html

It seems to me that you are mistaking what the substance is used for locally for what it will do when in the atmosphere globally. CO2 absorbs infrared instead of letting it pass which heats up the gas and in turn... heats up the atmosphere. You keep ending your comments with, "Why do you get dumber the more you are taught?". Maybe you shouldn't be so judgmental considering this pseudoscience you just spouted out without sourcing.

Edit: This is probably what got you mixed up about CO2 acting as a coolant... read the full study... it only cools the stratosphere and mesosphere... while warming the surface and troposphere.

text: @Fathom  let me explain it in a way you can visualise. Imagine a basket of apples, to which two new apples get added every hour. You eat two apples per hour as well, so the number of apples remain constant, however, if we add four apples per hour, it exceeds the rate of consumption, and leads to an eventual collapse of the system. That is what occurs with greenhouse gases, which are contributors to climate change. For millions of years, we were producing just enough to maintain a consistent and stable environment, however, with the exponential increase in consumption of fossil fuels that resulted from the industrial revolution, we are, putting out much more than can be retained. That is why this is different, that is why even though we've existed for millennia, with the same exchange and cycle of gases, we are now facing what we never have before. No one is forcing you to pay extra taxes you don't want to, or nod along to every thing the government says, but if you're still denying climate change, you're something else. We're producing more than can be balanced, and we're exhausting our resources at an unprecedented rate, THIS WAS THE WHOLE GODDAMN PLOT OF INFINITY WAR

text:
Everybody laughed at Mitt Romney's joke (5:58) about Obama promising to slow the rise of the oceans, as if to say it's silly to think humans can effect such a change. Yet he supports the idea that the oceans are rising as a result of human activity. Make up your mind, Mitt.

But even if it was unintentional, he is correct that human behavior doesn't lead to climate change. Meteorological changes are occurring on all of the planets, not just Earth.Are humans causing the changes on Jupiter?

The climate IS changing but humans are not causing it and CO2 is not a factor.
- Temperature change precedes CO2 levels, it doesn't follow it.
- CO2 is good. It is plant food. When CO2 levels have been highest, plant life flourished.
- The climate has always fluctuated, both long and short term. And no matter what the global norm is, there are areas of deviation. The Earth has systems that mitigate the human contribution. 

Learn the real science:
- Why "Global Warming" Failed & Why Climate Change is Real
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5c4XPVPJwBY
- Global Warming in a Climate of Ignorance | Space News
https://www.thunderbolts.info/wp/2017/03/04/global-warming-in-a-climate-of-ignorance-space-news/
- Global Warming and Our Electric Sun | Space News:
https://www.thunderbolts.info/wp/2017/03/11/global-warming-and-our-electric-sun-space-news/
- Sacrifice, Delusion and Climate
http://www.thunderbolts.info/tpod/2011/arch11/110509climate.htm

Finally, before you place too much stock in news reports, check this to see how easy it is to let bad science and fraudulent data slip into the science journals:
- How three MIT students fooled the world of scientific journals
https://news.mit.edu/2015/how-three-mit-students-fooled-scientific-journals-0414

author: Justin Noker

text:
'something needs to be done', 'we need to get gas powered cars off the roads'

With a bit of research you'll find there are numerous things everyone can be doing instead of just suggesting one idea or saying 'something needs to be done' 
- eat less meat (especially beef, switch to chicken, or even better eat no meat but I understand a lot of people are sensitive about that so just EAT LESS) 
- Eat locally produced food that hasn't trabelled thousands of miles.
- buy second hand, don't be so quick to throw away items

Honestly there are loads of things everyone can be doing RIGHT NOW, but the biggest impact on the environment isn't CO2 from cars (which is mainly from industry), it's from the meat and dairy industry - it is just simple fact that it is an incredibly inefficient method of creating food for ourselves, while also producing huge amounts of methane from the unnecessary amount of livestock.

Here's an article on a recent study that highlights just how inefficient and damaging the meat and dairy industry is. (I know it's a liberal paper but it's analysing objective facts in a scientific study) https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/may/31/avoiding-meat-and-dairy-is-single-biggest-way-to-reduce-your-impact-on-earth

text: One of the biggest problems with fossil fuels, and why we're slow to act on climate change, is because of how volatile and political it is as a resource. It's prices can swing wildly depending on the current state of international politics, and can cripple economies that depend on them. Furthermore, our dependence on them may as well be a contract with the devil. If you are employed by the fossil fuel industry in any way, you have zero incentive to comprehend, understand, or accept Climate Change because your livelihood depends on it. If Americans were more green, I doubt we'd maintain questionable military alliances with countries like Saudi Arabia, who have some of the worst human rights records on the planet, let alone among our allies.

text:
Did you know that forestation has increased in the world since 1990? Most countries have increased their forests, including Europe. It's true, that it's not the case of Brazil but, deforestation has decreased dramatically in the last 15 years. In 2004, 27.000 km2 of deforestation happened. In 2013, last year with data), 5.000 km2 (+80% less).

What I mean is that deforestation was a BIG problem the last decade, but it's been already better addressed than expected, and the global trend is increasing forests.

In Europe, Agriculture is 8% of the total emissions. Actually, if you don't spend your holidays using the plane, you save much more CO2 than not eating meat. Or having efficient fridge and air condition. And if you replace beef with chicken or pork, you already get 70% of the cut emissions..

You're source simply is not reputable, and you can't expect people to put too much stock in it. author: Nate

text:
Zoe Phin "Green technologies" or products of the "Climate Change Industry" cover a huge array of products, even bigger than fossil fuels. They are basically anything that produces energy with no emissions. In other words, they are renewable technologies that can last indefinitely as long as they are maintained. 
Solar farms and wind farms do need maintenance, but not as much maintenance as coal fire plants. They also don't rely on finite fuel supplies. 
But in the end, a dying fossil fuel economy would be bad for the economy, given how much money it generates. 
The Republicans treat this idea of renewable self-dependence as if it is a bad thing. How can depending on renewable energy be worse than basing your entire infrastructure around a finite resource that puts your country at the mercy of other authoritarian foreign powers? And they still have the audacity to rant about "globalism" lol.
author: Nate

text:
klutz395 
https://principia-scientific.org/renewable-energy-simply-won-t-work-top-google-engineers/

"Koningstein and Fork aren’t alone. Whenever somebody with a decent grasp of maths and physics looks into the idea of a fully renewables-powered civilised future for the human race with a reasonably open mind, they normally come to the conclusion that it simply isn’t feasible. Merely generating the relatively small proportion of our energy that we consume today in the form of electricity is already an insuperably difficult task for renewables: generating huge amounts more on top to carry out the tasks we do today using fossil-fuelled heat isn’t even vaguely plausible.

Even if one were to electrify all of transport, industry, heating and so on, so much renewable generation and balancing/storage equipment would be needed to power it that astronomical new requirements for steel, concrete, copper, glass, carbon fibre, neodymium, shipping and haulage etc etc would appear. All these things are made using mammoth amounts of energy: far from achieving massive energy savings, which most plans for a renewables future rely on implicitly, we would wind up needing far more energy, which would mean even more vast renewables farms – and even more materials and energy to make and maintain them and so on. The scale of the building would be like nothing ever attempted by the human race."

text:
Cutting greenhouse emissions means a lot more than just buying "super expensive" green technologies. The simplest way to cut greenhouse gasses is to just consume less. You don't have to buy anything to cut your own consumption. If you consume less you are helping the environment and saving money. And if you have to buy something like a car isn't it better that that car was made efficiently and it consumes less? And if you are scared you don't need to buy anything. Why don't you want a car that consumes less and makes more power with less fuel? I don't understand. We have 1l (1000cc) engines today that produce over a 100 bhp. I think that's incredible. One reason for this is because companies are conforming to regulations. Without regulations and public demand for lower consumption there is little incentive for companies to develop more efficient engines and push the limits of technology. This applies to other industries too. But not oil, gas and coal. The less efficient your car is, the more oil or electricity you spend the more money they make. They have no incentive to have you consume less. This is the conflict of interest. And you can see politicians will tell you w     

Every new technology is expensive in the beginning. Think cell phones and computers in the 90s. But once these new technologies start being mass produced they will bring jobs and economic growth without polluting. Why is that a bad thing?
Sure there were people back in the 80s and 90s who were scared of computers but you aren't writing to YouTube on a typewriter are you?

text:
Well that mentality isn’t going to help. At all. Acknowledging the problem helps none if people ignore it, or in your case, GIVE UP. Humans are an incredibly adaptable species, it’s kind of our defining trait. Sure, we can’t STOP the effects of climate change, but we can adapt to it, mitigate it, even reverse it given enough time. Vote with the environment in mind, reduce meat portions, if you can’t take public transit or bike, drive the least amount possible, park at the closest parking space to save gas.

And never, never give up hope. When you give up hope, you make the task all the more daunting, because everyone else has to deal with your pessimistic self.

Yes it’s bad, yes if we could go back we could do better, but instead of focusing on what’s occurred, accept it as fact and use that as a basis for how to move foreword.

We’ve got this. When I stop dedicating my life for the safety of nature and Earth’s ecosystems, I will have died.

- a man who has hope

text:
@Generation Fallout  
It's no longer a question of "giving up"... it's a question of acknowledging reality. It's not "giving up" to acknowledge that your house has burned down because of your foolish habit of smoking in bed... your house has burned down, and now that's an indelible fact, as is your complicity in it's having gotten to such a state. The time to hope for a better outcome passed when you failed to put out your cigarette before nodding-off.

Likewise, in the case of climate change, the forces involved have already reached a tipping point. We should have taken collective action decades ago, but we chose not to. Now we're paying the price, and our children will pay a greater price, and our grandchildren, a greater price still. While that fact should not stop us from continuing to do all we can to ensure the survival of our species, the truth is that fighting for survival is all we've got left, and it's far from an achievable goal now. And given our track-record to date, I'd lay grim odds on our likelihood of even rising to that challenge.

You can thank people like "Mr. Laughs" for that.

author: Richi_Boi

text:
1. Vote, and choose politicians who don't pretend that it's all a Chinese hoax. This is by far the most important point - the rich and powerful control the world, at least try to make it so the powerful are not deniers with that little power of choice that is afforded to you - don't let China get away with saying that authoritarianism beats democracy on climate change

2. Reduce your meat consumption and/or prefer chicken to other meats - 1Kg of chicken takes just 20% of the resources compared to 1Kg of beef

3. When possible try to prefer green alternatives in everything you buy, but for god's sake RESEARCH what is actually 'green' before marching down the roads with "no nuclear" signs (nuclear is actually great for climate change since a few tonnes underground are better than billions of tonnes in our air and lungs)

3.1. Point 3 withstanding, remember that it's almost always better to KEEP a functioning non-green product over buying a new shiny green one if you don't actually need the replacement. Green things are great but producing them also harms the environment. EG don't throw away your 2-year-old gasoline car to buy a Tesla

4. Transport modes from best to worst:

- Bycicle/foot
- Subway/Train in states and countries that use at least some nuclear and/or renewables
- Bus/Other public transport + Subway/Train in states and countries that run only fossil
- Electric, hydrogen, methane, LPG, diesel*, gasoline car in this order
- Airplane (yes this is WORSE than gasoline and diesel)

* On diesel: diesel is far WORSE than anything when it comes to pollution , that is, poisonous particles that directly harm your body. However, from a thermodynamic standpoint it is more efficient than gasoline, which means it emits less CO2. Contrary to popular belief, CO2 and particulate are two separate things - particulate harms us and animals immediately like a poison, CO2 worsens global warming and harms the planet in the long run. With diesel you are trading our immediate physical health for a slight CO2 reduction compared to gasoline - I'd suggest not having to make that trade in the first place. Note: because particulate is really bad in cities, don't get diesel if you drive in cities as critical levels will cause it to be banned more and more in there.

But whatever happens, life, in some form, will go on. Likely even for some humans. But, forget about having a laissez-faire attitude toward life and expecting all of the modern comforts we've come to take for granted. It will be a hard life and for many more it will be even harder and likely impossible. Millions, if not billions, will die and while most will be in poorer nations richer nations will not escape the impact. It will be much like the other "great dyings" that have occurred throughout Earth's history accept, as you said, it will occur relatively rapidly. text:
@Mert Garbonite  oh yeah, if you think you've considered everything the scientists haven't. Think again, read an actual paper on the subject by a major journal and you'll be sorely disappointed in your politicians.

CO2 is a natural gas, but the system usually consists of both carbon sinks and carbon sources. There are natural sources like volcanos and natural forest fires and there are sinks like growing forests and the oceans are both depending on the relative saturation between the atmosphere and the water. But even if humans only add a small amount, it's a small amount that has nowhere to go in this already balanced system. Things where in equilibrium for a bit but now it's got a much heavier input.

Now the oceans and atmosphere are receiving most of our input and the effect of CO2 in atmosphere leading to a greenhouse effect have been recorded and known for over 120 years. It's basically fact. What's more concerning for me (as a marine conservation scientist) is that it also saturates the oceans and as the carbon dioxide is dissolved into the water, it disaccoiates into carbonic acid.

In case you hadn't noticed, the majority of marine life uses calcium based shells and skeletons. In an acid medium, these will all be dissolved which isn't just cruel and painful, it means the end of all marine snails, crustaceans and corals as well as many more delicate organisms (ever seen a nudibranch? One of the most amazing slugs you'll ever see, but they could quite easily be wiped out by this).

Just remember, it's not that climate change is happening. It's that humans are making it happen way too fast. Species can evolve and survive, but at this rate we'll be lucky to have anything alive in 100 years.

text:
Widget I've read a bunch of papers, all of them seem to be confused on the subject of how to model the sinks of carbon dioxide as they change with c02 or at least I still dont understand it. As we get more co2 vegetation increases and absorbs more c02. Is that the only negative feedback factor besides our radiation increasing? If what your saying is true and the system is balanced and any perturbation of co2 will be unbalanced the system is unstable.  Then how did life survive back when there was tons of co2? Did they not have bones or shells ?

 I guess the Crux of the question is, the earth system is inherently stable somehow, If it were not we would get snowball earth with runaway albido. Or become mars with runway heating forever ago. So what makes earth stable, why cant this factor fix the issue, how is aquatic life structurally different now than in the eocene or other high co2 periods and how do we trust the predictions of models which seem to always include a "tipping point" when we know such a thing would have tipped us already by now. Isnt the essence of science that if our theory doesnt hold up to reality even once it's wrong?

 I'm not gonna argue about complex food chains and biology... that I'm just curious about seeing as your the expert. I'm pretty scientifically literate and I've read the atmospheric studies for global warming and seen them updated again and again, at some point it's not a constant in front of the variable you gotta change it's the variables your considering. 

I believe we are causing to some degree climate change and I believe it will damage the earth and the ecosystems.  I just dont see the evidence of it being catastrophic or unprecedented. I strongly believe in my lifetime we will have fusion power and ubiquitous electric vehicles, China already had a fusion source going for over a minute. Lockheed says 2025 there's will be running.  Then we will need no more co2 for power production, how can everything fall apart before then. What am I missing ? I can handle the science no need to simplify anything that's what has led to my confusion in the first place.
