text:
Mert... I don't doubt the potential of fusion power or the potential for leaving fossil fuels in the near future - provided the political obstacle can get over it. And I admit. I'm a marine conservation scientist so I have my field of expertise and there are many others I would have to investigate before I could call myself a full climate expert (especially since I look into the biology side more than the physiochemical side) but that doesn't limit what I've read and seen. I'd like you to link me to these confused papers you describe so I can see if it's just interpretation or if it's the sourcing  that's a little off... I know when I started reading around one subject I was googling the definitions of every other word just to keep up with the paper but as you get used to the language used, it gets easier to read them... And coffee helps immensely... 

The problem with climate change is not that 'it's happening' but that its happening way too fast. Imagine this: 

The last little ice age around 10,000 years ago was a cold point and after that, the world started warming. Then we hit the medieval warm period and it began to cool again until the got industrial and global temperatures began to pull up and as the human race industrialised, our carbon output magnified exponentially. You can understand that there is a limited amount of carbon on earth and that before we started burning coal, it was largely contained underground in oil and coal deposits. When we began to dig those up and burn it, we started bringing that carbon out of the ground stores and into the atmosphere. From there it has to deposit somewhere so it can dissolve into the oceans through a process called 'atmospheric deposition' and yes, for a while it will result in an increase in plant growth - but I'll get back to that later - it's not as simple as they want you to believe (every time I hear that argument my inner ecologist just screams). This carbon source and sink theory is pretty well founded and yes, it does reflect reality. It can be simplified to the simple idea of 'concentration gradients' - if anything is highly concentrated and there is nothing causing it to hold together (temperature is uniform/no static charges etc) then the concentration will diffuse 'down the gradient' and alike molecules will separate (it's the same concept that means oxygen will diffuse into your blood and carbon dioxide with diffuse out of your blood in the lungs but the gases don't stop each other from diffusing in opposite directions) so the oceans act as a giant global sink for just about anything in the atmosphere - ocean acidification is a simple chemical process that occurs when carbon dioxide is diffused into water - a polar molecule (as in it has little micro-electric charges on the molecule due to a concept known as 'electronegativity - this means that it only allows things to dissolve in it if it's molecules can be made equally polar - so salt dissolves into it's ions of sodium and chloride and in this case - Carbon Dioxide dissolves into carbonic acid. That's the chemistry bit done so if you're all good with that - let's move on to why this screws marine life.

Limestone is Calcium Carbonate - it is made of the fossilised remains of calcium based lifeforms - largely a kind of phytoplankton called 'coccolithophores' but impurities remain in the form of anything also fossilised that isn't explicitly calcium carbonate based (- a fish skeleton isn't a carbonate and sharks don't have traditional bones) and this (in case you haven't seen the White Cliffs od Dover in the UK) makes up quite a huge amount of marine organisms - crustaceans (all crabs, lobsters and shrimps) have an exoskeleton made of this stuff (and shrimps or krill make up a hugely important component of fish diets (it's the reason salmon is pink, ask if you're unsure) which would have a drastic knock-on effects on fish stocks globally. Not to mention all shellfish in general would suffer and struggle to maintain populations - marine snails, clams, starfish, sea urchins and sea cucumbers (lovingly nicknamed the 'trashmen of the sea' for their role in material recycling. I include Echinoderms like starfish because they too have calcareous skeletons). Hope that's not too much, it's just about 6 textbooks worth of reading condensed into a rather specific topic. (Don't even get me started on corals - it would be another paragraph just like this one).

 Let's get to the feedback argument. 

The stability argument you make (or as I interpret it, clearly communicated ideas and answers are hard to come by but that's what's so great about the internet - near instant communication! We'll figure it out, don't you worry) comes from the point that the earth is a continually feedback influenced system. If albedo was to increase due to less sea ice - the water would be absorbing more of the sunlight than would have been reflected by the ice. Agreed? (Sorry, I need to know at which point this stops making sense to you, okay?) The water absorbs more sunlight and thus warms up more than with the sea ice overhead causing the water to expand (that's right, water expands with increasing temperature, water at around 4 degrees C is the densest water and it's why deep sea water is usually that temperature it sinks below colder and hotter water - not certain about the exact hydrodynamics though, I'm not an oceanographer). The expanded water takes up more land under it's area and the global ocean area is now a little bigger - allowing for more heat input from sunlight and causing further expansion. As the temperature increases at the surface, more evaporation takes place too, resulting in more sudden and violent storms (again, not a meteorologist but by understanding says this heating up is in no way good for land or for sea).  

Now, the actual problem with all of this climate change debacle is the pace it happens at. If the oceans only got slightly more acidic a little bit over a few thousand years, the species' as a whole that live there would have evential adaptations to let them survive and live into the next epoch. Same goes for terrestrial changes - if the oceans where to rise slowly over a few thousand years, then salt marsh species would be able to retreat with the land and nothing would really go extinct until an ecological collapse occurs (when enough species vital to the existence of an ecosystem - like trees in a forest or corals for a reef - where to stop living and stop existing. Essentially ending that environment and leaving the organisms that depend on that environment with adaptations that do them no favours at all - resulting in a chain of extinctions). 

What humans do however, is find news ways to force things to happen faster and more efficiently so of course we found almost all of the world's carbon deposits and released almost all of it into the atmosphere in just a few centuries (no normal volcano or even chain of volcanoes could do what we have already done). Humans have one thing I appreciate greatly - we can do things like no other species ever could. No beaver can make a dam like humans can, no bird can fly as high, no worm can dig as deep, no fish can swim as far and through technology we have almost broken this world. The least we could do is give at least some other organisms time to evolve and catch up with the new epoch we have created. 

By now, I hope I have outlined some of the mechanisms, of course having my oceanographer friend alongside me would help but she's on the other side of the planet right now currently investigating the effects of ocean acidification of coccolithophores. I realise that you will still have many many questions about the specifics of why this is such a bad thing and I can do my best to interpret exactly what it is you don't quite click with and why but that's why we need to end the shouting war and start communicating clearly and honestly. If there is anything I've described that doesn't quite make sense to you, reply with a clear and concise question on what it is you don't quite click with and I'll do my best to help.

The absolute best thing you can do (if it's an option) is get a full education or listen to those that make the most sense - stay rational and logical and always be skeptic of an argument until it is certainly proven. 

Also, love thy fellow humans. Be excellent to each other.

text: Climate change is the perfect challenge that faces humans. Our brains fail to process climate change because it is exceptionally amorphous. It provides us with no defining qualities that would give it a clear identity: no deadlines, no geographic location, no single cause or solution and, critically, no obvious enemy. Our brains scan it for the usual cues that we use to process and evaluate information about the world, but find none. It defies the human psyche to take action to this threat and ultimately will lead to our downfall.

author: Garrett Wright

text: dw5050 Yet you provide no actual insight on how you know this, you simply act as if it is ridiculous to assume that people could be skeptical of climate change. I took an entire AP Environmental Science course in high school, and I am still on the fence.
author: Garrett Wright

text: @Garrett Wright  Taking AP enviro does not qualify you to refute some of the most widely held views in climatology based on intuition alone. What groundbreaking piece of extraordinary evidence do you have that refutes the greenhouse effect? If you're not refuting the greenhouse effect then you must be denying the fact that greenhouse gas emissions even exist? Which unsupportable denial of widely accepted evidence are you going for, exactly?
author: dw5050

text: I was not claiming it qualified me for anything, I'm simply stating the weird adverse effect it had on my opinion. My problem is not that I can refute it, it is that I haven't been convinced. Again, I'm not saying it actually exists, I'm simply saying that there are reasonable criticisms of ANTHROPOGENIC climate change. Things like how the hockey graph has been disproven, along with false predictions made by the world's most prestigious climate scientists, has made me skeptical, that's all. I am not denying the greenhouse effect or the existence of greenhouse gas emissions, I'm really just curious as to how the small amount that we put out as compared to the atmosphere of our entire planet has really affected the climate as drastically as scientists have claimed. Again, I understand the whole claim that just because the number sounds small doesn't mean it is, but I have acquireed no information as to why it doesn't matter that it's so small.
author: Garrett Wright

text: @Garrett Wright  If you haven't been convinced, then you simply have not sought out any convincing evidence yourself. Watch a basic 3 minute video right here on youtube called "Causes and Effects of Climate Change" by Nat Geo if you need convincing. If that's not good enough for you, go visit NASA's climate change evidence page: climate dot nasa dot gov slash evidence (youtube blocks comments with links in it sometimes). Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere haven't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years. Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have increased by almost a third since the industrial revolution. We have satellite imagery tracking the progression of the melting polar ice caps which are melting at accelerating speeds, in accordance with the accerating rise in average surface temperatures... You've been distracted by industry apologists who are moving the goal posts from "are humans causing climate change" to "how MUCH are humans causing climate change" even though the body of evidence in support of anthropogenic climate change isn't nearly as ambiguous as they're making it out to be.
author: dw5050

text: @dw5050 There are a couple discrepancies in that NatGeo video. Firstly, they discuss how the melting glaciers have already led to the flooding of coastal cities, and cut to an image of a flooded neighborhood. I think it is safe to say that no neighborhoods are permanently flooded yet, right? I'm sure that they took this picture from after a horrible storm, so that is blatant misinformation on their part. The graphs that they show aren't a very strong argument to me, and here's why. They show the increase in temperature, then the increase of carbon dioxide. The hockey stick-looking increase in the Carbon Dioxide graph has already been statistically disproven, yet we still show it in textbooks and youtube videos. Lastly, here is something I found very interesting the first time I heard it, and NatGeo was pretty ignorant to this. NatGeo claims that the rise in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere would end in world-wide drought and the lack of accessibility of clean water. But that just isn't reality. The Sahara desert, millions of years ago, was a rainforest. If you raise temperatures, you raise the possibility of evaporation and precipitation. If you raise that possibility of evaporation and precipitation, you receive a wetter climate. If anything, we would facilitate more of a jungle world than we would a desert, because it isn't like all of this water can go anywhere. It is stuck in our atmosphere and has to return as precipitation eventually. I feel that this video was either intentionally uninformed or new facts have been discovered since its filming.

text:
There's still plenty of profit to be had in alternative energy. So many of these technologies are relatively new, and there are many technologies that haven't even begun yet. It's just that coal, oil and natural gas are well established and very well developed. The cheapest and easiest is always going to be ground zero in a huge war anytime someone threatens the power base that has grown up around it. Like any dangerous animal, it will fight to the death when its territory and existence is threatened.

If we make it past this ultimate test, new battles will be fought over new energy technologies, and people of the future, if there is one for us, will look back on who we are right now and make mean jokes about us savages burning coal and oil actually literally in our homes, choking on the fumes and drooling over stupid shows on television. We will be the primitive roots of the human species that were too stupid to care about our own future. Humans of the future will compare us to humans of the dark ages, wallowing in our own waste and caring about nothing but our individual needs.

At least I hope so. All I see right now is hot, blowing sand, dead trees and the forgotten bones of billions.

text: It's really sad. I don't have much confidence in how well this is going to turn out for the world. I thought we all agreed that things had to change, but then nothing changed. I see more and more people living indulgent lifestyles: Driving big trucks they don't need. Buying big homes they don't need. Eating more than they need. It's all a part of the same issue. Americans don't understand minimalism and reduction. The Christian values in this country have corrupted our culture. We simply believe we should take what we want, because it was given to us by God. Nothing has changed. 75 Percent of Americans identify as Christian... 75 percent of Americans still believe that they can take what they believe they need from God's green Earth. No matter what advancements we've made in science in the past 100 years, we still act on the same old fashioned desires.  The idea of a big family with a big home. The strong dad that knows how to handle a hammer and drives a big manly truck while he eats a lot of meat and drinks beer with the beautiful wife that stays at home and cooks all of the meals for the family.  I'm not being ironic here. This old country lifestyle that people so badly want in America is the reason why NO ONE wants to act on climate change. It means letting go of this pipe dream, and they will grasp onto literally any thread that suggests a drop of credibility in climate change deniers.

text:
Hijacking this comment to start a discussion on nuclear energy. 

What do you all think about transitioning the United States to majority nuclear power? France already does it with 75% of their energy coming from nuclear and 90% coming from nuclear and hydroelectric. It's the safest form of energy by death count, produces only a fraction of the waste of conventional sources, uses little land area, is estimated to be effectively renewable for the next few billion years, and can be one of the cheapest sources where France has one of the lowest electricity costs in the world because of it.

Thoughts?

text:
@Donna Willams  What truth ? Do you know what precession is ? They keep saying that they do not know what creates Climate Change, that is bull, I know and so will you after watching this geological documentary. And if we know, then they should know, certainly the scientists. Climate change is a natural mechanism of nature, we can't stop that even if we put all the money we have on earth in it. We can't stop the wobble of our earth, but humans are just unwilling to accept that nature is stronger then them. 

NOT saying we shouldn't be less polluting as humanity, but there simply are things we can not change, and nature is one of them. We do not cause precession as the soil research proves this mechanism has been influencing Earth for centuries. It happened before we build cars and factories, and it will happen long after humanity is extinct. 

So the whole idea that we humans can change this is an illusion. Instead we should focus on how to deal with it, instead of thinking we can prevent it as we can't ! 

This scientific geology documentary will show the cause of climate change, and you can verify it in the Chinese and US deserts as well, as the desert belt is not only located in the sahara. So there various ways to verify this further, but since humanity is in denial, i guess it will take years before the mass of humanity will know about this. Hope i'm contributing to speed it up so we can deal with it, instead of focussing on useless ways to deal with it and reporter after reporter saying they do not know what causes climate change.

author: Mr. Worm

text:
Hector Graciano 
Another correction. Every "volcanoes don't emit much co2" article will reference Gerlach. Why?

" point of fact, the total worldwide estimate of roughly 55 MtCpa is by one researcher, rather than "scientists" in general. More importantly, this estimate by Gerlach (1991,2011) is based on emission measurements taken from only seven subaerial volcanoes and three hydrothermal vent sites. Yet the USGS glibly claims that Gerlach's estimate includes both subaerial and submarine volcanoes in roughly equal amounts. Given the more than 3 million volcanoes worldwide indicated by the work of Hillier & Watts (2007), one might be prone to wonder about the statistical significance of Gerlach's seven subaerial volcanoes and three hydrothermal vent sites. "
author: Zoe Phin

text:
@Zoe Phin   How many of the 3 million volcanoes are potentially active? It would be 1,500,according to usgs. gov. That makes 2,998,500 of the volcanoes you mentioned,dormant or extinct.

It's not exactly accurate because you said "more than 3 million",but I need a number to work with.
author: Mr. Worm

text:
Hector Graciano 
"Active" means magma flows. Magma flows are not necessary for co2 outgassing.
author: Zoe Phin

text: @Zoe Phin  Then how do they release CO2 if they are not active?
author: Mr. Worm

text:
Hector Graciano 
Active means too much. A volcano that seeps gases but not magma flows is "not" "active". You may think that makes it active, but that's not the technical geological definition.

The earth will procede from a hot ball, farting out all its gases until it's a cold dead rock. Any doubt about this?
author: Zoe Phin
